description: Went for dinner.  The menu, like the decor, is a mishmash.  Portions are massive.  The food is ok.  Service was mediocre. It feels like a badly done Cheesecake Factory and something you are more likely to find in LA.
author: E L.

description:
It always seems to be a dilemma whenever I have to go eat somewhere with my father and sister, when I'm the odd vegan out.
We stopped by the place that my sister and I are moving into in Noe Valley and then proceeded to walk around for quite a few minutes before settling on Savor. It turned out there were a few things I could eat and I ended up ordering the Bangkok salad but substituting tofu for chicken. The salad was quite good. Mixed greens with red onions, peanuts, lots and lots of tofu, all topped off with a spicy lemongrass vinaigrette. I felt like it could have used more veggies and a little less lettuce, but it was still good. What I really liked was the fact that the tofu was cubed and was firm. I've been to plenty of places (even Herbivore) where I add tofu to something and it's just too soft. Bravo on that one, Savor.
I also ordered a side of house potatos which were alright.

The reason for 3 stars would be the lack of variety for my own sake and the price of the salad. My salad was huge and was $10.25. For the size of the salad, I guess I could justify the price. There's definitely a chance I could be back, but I definitely want to see that I could do better in Noe Valley.

My dad ordered a salad with salmon on it, and my sister ordered a crepe with eggplant and artichokes. My dad really liked his salmon and my sister liked her crepe.
author: Amanda M.

description:
Today, I had the soft crab sandwich with lemon-garlic aioli sauce and coleslaw.

It was simply AMAZING.

and my waiter David was, as always, adorable and super nice. 

Love this place.
author: Casey M.

description: I've heard a lot of good things about this place, so I decided to take my two Texan friends there for breakfast. They've already been to Chloe's, Pomelo was closed, so Savor it was gonna be for Noe Valley. We were the only ones in the outdoors dining room and received the most attentive service from David. I had a smoked salmon scramble, one of my friends had a Monte Cristo, and I forget what my other friend had because I was very into my food. I was starving, and the portions were HUGE! Really, unbelievably so. Despite that, we tried to finish everything so that it wouldn't go to waste. SO satisfying! The best breakfast and service I've had in a while. Yes, the items were standard, but honestly, sometimes that's hard to find in SF, and I miss that a little bit coming from NYC. I heart Savor!
author: Marina S.

description:
Wow... how on earth could this place have a 3 1/2 avg. star rating? We are in San Francisco, land of delicious brunch! And this place is seriously anything but that. 

1. The service SUCKS. Like, never filled our water once, didn't even ask us what we wanted forever, totally sucks. 

2. The bf got an omelet with sausage cheese and mushroom. And not only was there a HAIR IN HIS FOOD, but the cheese was totally bland and the whole thing was just a big flavorless fat-filled disaster. 

3. I got granola with yogurt and berries. The granola was total crap (seriously I've gotten better (way better) from Costco), the plain yogurt was probably the cheapest they could get, and the strawberries (which were the only berries in it) were mushy. They even went in there and cut out little bits of the strawberries where they were particularly nasty. I mean how gross is that?! 

There are so many delicious brunch places (just walk down the street for heaven's sake!) so do NOT waste your brunch calories on this place or else you, like me, will leave in a horribly sour deliciousness-deprived mood.
author: Heather W.

description:
I'm not a big fan of cornbread, but a friend ordered it as an appetizer. It comes with jalapeño jelly. The cornbread is sliced like a piece of bread instead of a cube. I think it's the best cornbread I've ever had.

It was a busy day for lunch (President's Day), and we had a short wait. The staff was very friendly, and they seemed to like each other. Service was good.

My pulled pork sandwich (the Carolina) was good, and my friend liked his chicken and waffles (the Del Rio). My fries were good - crispy, but not too thin.

Portions were big. I'll definitely go back.
author: gary y.

description:
Yay...I AM a fan...especially of our waitress here! Totally have the hots for her (no lesbo...okay, maybe lesbo). She was super hot and sweet!

Okay, now that that's outta my system. the food is good. Just good. It'll definitely satisfy you if you're hungry and/or hungover. The price is decent and the ambiance is fantastic for beautiful sunny days. They have a back patio that's covered and very pleasant to be in when it's warm out. The host and other servers are very friendly and kind as well.

I ordered the Costa del Sol (ham/eggs Benedict, came with a cup of fruit salad and potatoes) and was satisfied. My brunchmate ordered their pumpkin pancakes, which were also pretty yummy. I wouldn't go gushing about either dish nor would I wait an excessive amount of time to have them, but it's definitely good stuff and well portioned. My only gripe is that the potatoes were wayyyyyy over salted. WHOA. I am a lover of potato in all forms (and carbs for that matter..mmmm) and I only ate a few cubes of it. Definitely not a good sign for someone like me.

All in all, good neighborhood spot for brunch. I give em a 3.5, but I'll round up for the cute waitress. There are other places I would recommend to out-of-town friends, but I like Savor and the outdoor seats beckon to me on lovely days. Thus, I will not exercise self discipline and will indeed return for MOAR!
author: Dwigt K. S.

description: Crepes.  Cornbread.  Jalapeño jam.  That about says it all!
author: David S.

description:
It's the 'what, wha-what...what!'  Yep, that's right, you heard it first or maybe second?  I just tried the corn bread with jalapeno jelly.  One word: frickendelicious.

Why has no one ever told me about this?  Darn them to hell-o.  I'm definitely going back this week.  For sure!
author: Ryan B.

description: I typically read bad reviews on here before I patronize a business, so I went to a birthday dinner here last night prepared for poorly cooked potatoes and inconsistent service. It was the only thing I retained from the negative reviews. I was absolutely amazed at what a great job the restaurant did for a birthday party group of around 40 people. From what I could see, the ONLY mistake in all those meals was that they made an 'extra' crepe dish, which nobody claimed. I inhaled the 2 meals I ordered-the 'Bangkok' (a delicious salad with chicken kebobs, and mint leaves) and the 'New Orleans' (a crab cake benedict). All perfectly made, and utterly delicious. And the portions were generous I might add. I eat a lot, so that is saying much, coming from me!
author: Richard V.

description: Don't have the soup! It was like dishwater with noodles and pieces of potato (so called 'vegetable noodle'). The server was nice and brought me a free coffee when I complained but I would not go back to Savor. I can't imagine letting something so disgusting come out of the kitchen. For shame!
author: C J M.

description:
I doubt Yelpers need to be told more about how good Savor is. This is my favorite eat-outside brunch place in San Francisco, which has a beautiful garden in the back, now complete with lots of canapes for sun protection. 

If you want enormous portions of excellent quality food, this is the place to be in Noe Valley. Get started with a pint-sized glass of Mimosa or Bloody Mary, alongside some Spicy Cornbread with Jalopeno Jelly. Then decide some variation of pancake, crepe, omelette or egg dish looks most delicious (a difficult decision to make, some of my favorites here are the soy bean chorizo omelette 'the Arizona', the pulled pork sandwich and the truly phenomenal salmon benedict 'the Cote d'Azur'. If you have room, finish with the Jamaica sweet crepe (with rum sauce) whilst continuing to sun yourself. 

The best of San Francisco brunching experiences.
author: Sarah F.

description: Great place! My friends and I got together for brunch on a Friday morning, we were seated in the patio... best thing Dog Friendly!!! I have a lil puppy, and I was happy that I was able to bring her in! I will be coming back!
author: Adree A.

description:
My friends and their baby, Claire (a big flirt with the servers). took me here this morning for brunch! They had so many California-inspired omelettes, house specials and savory crepes on the menu it was hard to decide!! But one of the egg scramble dishes, Provance, with fresh salmon with spinach, onions and goat cheese caught my eye. 

It was absolutely delicious and came with a bagel, a generous servings of home potatoes! One of my friends had Mazatlan crepe with sliced avocado, tomatoes, sharp cheddar cheese and chipotle peppers with salsa fresca and sour cream. 

From the outside, Savor looks tiny, but once you cross its threshold, it opens up to a very spacious restaurant complete with a fireplace in the back and a private courtyard that I'm sure is just fabulous in the summer. I look forward to my next visit to this ever-so-charming and lovely Noe Valley neighborhood.
author: Jenny D.

description: Took my daughters father here for fathers day. A little bit of a wait but all in all a good  experience. Hostess had other things going on and was a little dismissive but there was a manager that seemed to be really on the ball. Food was good- I had the crab cakes Benedict and he had Belgium waffle and omelette. Only negative was the fruit salad in the cup ha been sitting for a while, but our daughters fruit plate was fresh. Definitely a great place for breakfast....
author: Diana D.

description: A nice place to have brunch with a large group.  They have a wide variety of food (crepes, salads, sandwiches, eggs, pancakes, etc.) and portions are huge.  I usually go for the Bangkok salad - I like the preparation of the chicken and it goes well with the other salad ingredients. I've only come here once when it wasn't brunch time and learned they have cheap glasses of wine!  Yay!
author: Sarah G.

description: I'm giving Savor 5 stars because they simply hit every check point on my "good restaurant"  check list. For starters the hostest was super super nice the Sunday morning we went, we were seated within 5 minutes even though we expected 10-15 minutes. Next I wanted inside seating and a manager came over and suggested outside patio and promised me it was covered and heaters kept the patio warm, Went to the patio and it was actually quite toasty and comfortable for a overcast 65 degree morning in Noe Valley. Next the waitress that took our order really knew the food and was able to describe every thing we asked a question about! She was enthusiastic, sweet and just a pleasure all around. Then came the food and EVERYBODY at the table was more than happy. It was nice to have breakfast with a new twist. Savor is on my good list and I cant wait to go back! Good job guys!
author: David H.

description: First time in Noe Valley, and came to Savor to eat. It was delicious! I ordered the day's special- fish tacos! The tacos were delicious! Nom-worthy! I am not even sure what everybody else ordered but they all looked delicious as well. I'll definitely be back to everything else on the menu!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Savor is one of my favorite weekend brunch spots. I'm vegetarian and my partner is gluten free, and we have a wide variety of options at Savor. We love the food, and the service is always attentive. Every vegetarian crepe is yummy, I love switching them up. The kyoto crepe with peanut sauce is one of my favs, but the milano italian crepe is great too. I had one cauliflower soup of the day that I didn't like once and the waiter took it off my bill. Other than that, every vegetarian crepe on the menu is awesome. I love the fresh salad and home fries that come with the crepes. Mimosas and coffee on the weekend makes a perfect combo. 

I can even bring the in-laws here when they are in town; they love the french toast and waffles. Even when it's crowded we don't have to wait that long because there is so much seating available here. Best of all, now that I have a puppy I appreciate the dog-friendly outdoor seating in the back.

Big portions! I always have leftovers.
author: max k.

description: Another one of my favorite places in Noe Valley.  Tasty, inexpensive food.  I especially love the jalapeño cornbread - I get it every time.  Dinner crepes and dessert crepes are equally delicious.  Nice outdoor patio also when the weather's good.
author: Brian C.

description:
When I lived in San Diego, I volunteered at the sport stadiums for fundraisers. Once I made quesadillas at the Rubio's stand. At first, I thought more = better.  Eventually I realized too much cheese = grease slide as the cheese consolidated back and the poor tortilla became a grease napkin.  

And this is what breakfast here is like. Maybe it's just me, but their breakfast is a bit too greasy to be good. Omelets, crepes, beef hash; I always end up asking why I ate here. Oh yeah, my bf really likes this place. So I never wanted to review this place before. 

Then, I came here for dinner. Much different experience. I ordered the braised boneless short ribs ($18)-delicious!  I love braised meats. How can one not like juicy meat that falls apart with the touch of a fork?  It came with baby squash and garlic mashed potatoes. My bf got the cioppino ($19). It's a bit spicy so be careful if you're sensitive to spicy foods. My initial thought on seeing chicken on the menu was "How boring". But the person next to me ordered it and it looked delicious.  So get it if you're in a chicken mood. Fairly large portions, but it better be for the price. They also charge $1/person for SF Health. 

Breakfast here on the weekend is extremely noisy and crowded.  Dinner here around 6pm on the weekday was nice and quiet.
author: Yan E.

description:
A friend aptly calls this neighborhood the land of strollers and dogs.  I call it Rockridge, West.

This is a solid breakfast joint, that fully accommodates for strollers and dogs in a huge back covered patio.

The breakfast food was OK - easy to navigate on the menu, appealing-looking, and large in the portions.  Potatoes did not please, unfortunately.  Eggs were wonderfully fluffy but lacking in flavor - so camouflaged in my particular instance with a drowning of beans and cheese.  Good hangover food.

Great people watching, despite certain monochromatic (in the stroller and dogs sense) qualities.  Friendly service.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Heads up, Savor has changed management in the last year or so.  It use to be GRRREAT, but on the last few visits, I have to say the dinning experience sucked, big time.  From being seated by a disgruntled hostess w/bad hair and unintended torn stockings, to a very, very, blah waitress.  I almost wanted my money back .  Not to mention that they could give a crap how you want your food prepared.  I'll skip the details.  Growning up in SF, my suggestion is to go to the Crepevine on Church Street which is owned by a Savor family member.  They share the same menu.  The food is better, the service is excellent, it's CHEAPER, and there is no attitude!!!

So there you have it!
author: Perry T.

description:
Savor used to be one of my favorite places to eat unfortunately until today!

I went to savor today to get lunch with a friend.  I ordered a crape with the great name "San Francisco". It was a salmon crape with green salad and house potatoes. We had to wait a bit to have our orders brought out, but we did not mind. Once the waitress brought out our orders we were happy to eat, the food looked delicious. I took a fork full of the salad, and everything looked and tasted ok, until I noticed someting moving on top of one of the salad leaves on my plate. I could not believe my eyes, but there I was, looking at the most disgusting creature I have ever seen, a fly larvae. It was squirming around on my salad and it made me sick to my stomach. Right away I told one of the waiters what was going on and to my shock I was tod to wait for my waitress. Here I was sitting staring at this disgusting creature, wondering how in the world did it get there and why was my waitress taking such a long time to come and deal with this. I could not wait any longer so I took this almost untouched, contaminated plate of food right to her. I told her about the larvae on my salad and to my great surprise she asked if I would like to order anthing else. I was so disgusted and afraid my next choice from the menu would reveal another live surprise, that I told her I was no longer hungry. The waitress apologized and told me she was taking my order off the total bill, thats all she said.

I left thinking that I would never return there again. This is most disturbing and disgusting. My suggesting for those who like this place and eat there often is check your food before you eat it, you never know what kind of hideous creature lurks in your food.
author: V S.

description:
A couple weeks ago, after seeing Wicked one last time before it leaves SF, my friend and I met up with some friends who live in Twin Peaks. Our friend took us here one chilly early evening around 5-6pm. It took me a while to decide what I wanted to eat because it all looked good and the ambiance was great. We were seated in the back room which overlooked the patio tables outside. 

I decided on the salmon sandwich - I can't remember the name of the dish. It came with a huge hunk of salmon, avocado, and greens. The bun was soft and the whole thing was uber delicioso! I also enjoyed the crispy potatoes it came with, as well as my mango iced tea :)

For dessert, we decided to order a crepe to share. My friend really wanted the apple one so we ordered one. When it came out, we noticed it had cheese in it! We tried it, but just couldn't bring ourselves to eat it. The cheese was too wierd. We asked the waiter if it always came that way. He looked confused and said it did, but we could order another one without cheese if we wanted. We did so, and it was soooo much better without it! They didn't charge us for the first one either. So, be warned if you order that crepe. 

Next time I'm in SF, I will definitely want to hit up the boutiques next door and try Savor again!
author: Ashley M.

description:
I'm the kind of guy that get's hooked on a favorite dish at a restaurant. For example, the lamb shewerma at truly med, or the turkey cranberry sandwich at specialties. Sometimes I think that there should be an option to Yelp a dish instead of an establishment....

Anyway, it's the Bangkok Salad for me at Savor. I'm sure that they have tons of other tasty dishes up in there. I don't care.  Give me the Bangkok salad cause it's too good to pass up.  Someday I may figure out how to make that one at home and Savor may have to make some cut-backs due to my absence.
author: Ryan W.

description:
I remember my first visit to Savor over 10 years ago. It was good then and it is still good now, in fact, very good. Food is gourmet, atmosphere pleasant and relaxed and service excellent. 

Yesterday afternoon with friends I had the Tuscany chicken crepe and for $10.00 I got a lot of food. Plenty of salad, home fries and lots of the fresh chicken with pesto filling. 

Savor also serves a delicious jalapeno bread with a sweet spicy dipping sauce. 

I was told by my friends that Savor is a good salad and breakfast place. One of our group had the Cesar salad, looked hearty and satisfying. 

I would like to go back for breakfast soon and try the pumpkin spice pancakes. Oh and the mango ice tea was good too.
author: Jonathan F.

description:
I feel bad, because I didn't la-la love this place. It was recommended to me by the woman I rented an apartment from for the weekend. Her recommendation for Bi-Rite Creamery was spot on, too. 

I need some grub before I boarded the plane back to LA and I didn't really want to eat the same place twice. 

This is a deceptively large place. It's very nicely laid out and if it was a warm day, I'm sure sitting outside is lovely. There was a weird vibe, though. I can't put my finger on it, but after days of being in San Francisco and having people be friendly, I was taken aback by how detached the staff seemed. 

All of the sandwiches have names of different Central/Northern areas. Charming? I don't know. I got the one with chicken, pesto, red onions, tomatoes and lettuce. It was good and I didn't have indigestion afterwards. (No small feat.) 

Would I come back? Well, I would have to come back with someone local and see if the vibe was just me coming down off a high of getting mad love from SF.
author: Kim J.

description: This place was a good value.  It had a classier interior then expected for having such an affordable menu.  Crepes were well done and accompanied by a healthy portion of salad and potatoes.  Entree salads were huge.  The crispy polenta was properly crispy on the outside and creamy on the inside.  Also $5-7 servings of wine which came in mini-carafes were nice, more than a glass worth.  Service was fine too.
author: Paul T.

description:
I was really craving brunch.. so my friend took me here.. we got here at like 5pm! (he takes forever + a day to get ready) so it was basically dinner.. 

i got a eggs benedict with smoked salmon.. it was good but towards the end the salmon got really salty.. i got a mimosa with it too but that was not good.. champagne tasted funny.. 

one thing i did really like that i didnt think i would was the toast with jalapeno jelly..  =)
author: JUDY L.

description:
Savor is a fairly safe bet if you happen to be in Noe Valley and want to grab breakfast/brunch.

Pros
- menu offers lots of choices: omelets, benedicts, sweet and savory crepes, sandwiches, salads, etc
- huge portions
- great outdoor seating area in the back

Cons
- I've been here a few times and nothing here has really stood out to me.
- The wait can be long depending on when you go.

In my opinion, there are better breakfast options in the area...try Toast Eatery a few doors down.
author: Vivian W.

description: This place was perfect. Sit In The garden in the back. Best sandwiches I've ever had. Great service. Best cherry soda and I will be back for sure! Savor!!!
author: Victoria T.

description: This was one of my favorite places for a while...the patio great on warm days and the fireplace cozy on cool ones...then I noticed the food was a bit inconsistent....depending on the chef, I guess.  But..the last time (and I do mean the LAST time)..I got up to leave and my low blood pressure woes kicked in and I was faint and had to ask for a glass of ice water and sit back down.  It was quite embarrassing.  The server complied, but no one ever came over to inquire about me or offer a word of encouragement or care.  That would have meant so much and I probably would have dared go back!!
author: Susan V.

description:
Banana-coconut pancakes???  Sounds odd, looked pretty good, tasted wonderful.  So go, get them, eat them with syrup, or not!

Savor is a crepe place in Noe Valley that is so much more than a crepe place.  We were there this morning at about 8:30 a.m. and we were among our peers.  Kate and I had the 2 kids in tow and I think every other table in the joint excepting maybe 2 was at least 1/2 peopled by children.  I didn't think San Francisco had many kids, but there they were... all of them.  There were tables with only one kid, many tables with two kids and even tables with 3 and 4 kids (I did a double take when I saw the 4, they all had the curly blond hair so I got the impression it was all the same family).

My wife and son had savory crepes and I had the pancakes and my daughter ate a little bit off of everyone else's plate.  ...   The pancakes were DELICIOUS!  I sort of fancy myself a pancake maker as my father used to make pancakes whenever we had someone over at the house in the morning or he would make them on the campground stove when we were out camping.  He made good pancakes.  I think I make pretty good pancakes as well, but Savor's pancakes are better.  They are big and fluffy with a little bit of goo in the middle (perfection really).  Add bananas to the pancake batter and then bananas and coconut to the top and you have one fantastic dish.  Real sweet and very filling.  

The small entry gives one the feeling that it will be packed, but there is plenty of room in the back and if it is warm out you can sit outside as well.  This morning it was wet and cold, so we stayed inside.  But, the kids went outside to their relatively enclosed outdoor seating area to play when we were almost done with our breakfast and mom and dad wanted another cup of coffee.

Folks working here are very friendly and patient - good when the restaurant is full of kids.
author: Jonathan D.

description: This is a great brunch spot! I went on a Sunday morning with a group of 4 and there was no wait. The restaurant has a lovely covered patio with a couple of TVs for games. I ordered the crab eggs benedict and it was pretty good. The food came quickly and the service was excellent. I would definitely go back!
author: Antoinette O.

description:
Savor is one of the mysteries of San Francisco to me. It is a bustling spot- smack in the middle of 24th street. It has a warm, welcoming window and the menu is long... Seemingly it will suit any 'ole noe valley family member. It has a happy hour with tasty treats and what we like to call: 'the Irish pour'. This last bit is what perplexes me. No one shares our love of the mid-week Savor happy hour. Where are all you parents who need a glass of wine before picking up the baby from the nanny? Oh wait- is that a unique need? ;) 
On a more serious note- Savor has great food and a very friendly waitstaff. We'd like to see more Noe Valley neighbors there.
author: Kathryn W.

description: My go to neighborhood Brunch spot. Strong coffee, delicious Baja Scramble.
author: Carol G.

description:
Savor is correct their food is really good. I love the fact they have the back patio available for people to eat on nice days!

Their service is grants them my 5 stars. Their Mimosas are great as well. This to me is San Francisco at it's finest. The people and the food in the neighborhood they are in just makes it a fantastic Combo.
author: Allan F.

description:
This is a great brunch place for a Sunday post church brunch.  Tucked away in the heart of Noe Valley, Savor is light, spacious and accommodating for larger parties.  

I ordered the same Rio Grande, eggs scramble  as last time, it's just too good!  The portions are huge and I have another half plate left over- dinner tonight!

I did find a small piece of hair in the food - not good, but I know it happens to all of us occasionally so I'll give them the benefit of the doubt and subtracted 1-star for it.
author: Jackie G.

description:
I've been here for every major eating occasion throughout the day (save 4th Meal) and never been disappointed. The first time I came here was with the g'rents, and granted this was after a dinner at Elephant Bar (think  upgraded Dennys -- a place the seniors love), but the food was (mostly) delicious. I had the pesto chicken crepe with homefries and small salad on the side, and it was more than enough for two meals. The entrees are better than the sides in my opinion, but that's what you're paying for, right?

While definitely great for any meal, this place specializes in brunch and lunch, but don't count it out on a nice evening. They have a heated outdoor area which is very quiet at night and can be a great place to take a date to feel like you're the only ones at the restaurant (well, you probably will be, but still). The patio is a great place to sit for brunch, though, to enjoy that fresh, clean Noe Valley air.b
author: Matthew S.

description: I love the Bangcok salad.  All of their food is very good and large servings.  Service is GREAT!!!  The servers are ALWAYS friendly and on it.  I love their ice tea.  It's a tropical flavor. I'll be back!
author: Julia M.

description:
Despite the mixed reviews, I think Savor is a solid lunch place in Noe Valley.  It's convenient for me, but  I can see how this place might be a pain in the neck if you're coming from out of the neighborhood.  There is always a line on weekends around Brunch time.  

I prefer to hit Savor in the off hours for dine-in, mainly because  I'm partial to their lunch options over the breakfast itmes.  Some of my favorites include the Kyoto Crepe with tofu, shitake mushrooms and peanut sauce; the Sonoma and Petaluma sandwiches and the Bangkok Salad.  The portions are huge and will easily sustain you for two meals.  Sanwiches come with both potatos and a heaping side of mixed greens.

It's not a cheap eat, but the space makes up for it.  I love Savor's back patio and the comfy indoor seating.  Come here on a cold evening for some chow and they even have a little fireplace going.
author: Kerry D.

description:
It was a rainy day and cravings were stifled by the closed sign pasted on the door of our favorite sushi joint so we stumbled our way to the next interesting place.  I was always curious of Savor.  Seemed to always be busy when we walk by in them mornings so why not try this place for dinner?

First dish: Ceviche ... verdict: disgusting! Hideous presentation looked like someone through up seafood all over my the bowl they served us.   Probably never try Ceviche ever again.  
2nd Dish: Trout  with mash potatoes ... verdict: Delicious!

What was lacking in the slow service was made up with the delicious trout served.  

I might try Ceviche another time but maybe in Mexico.

Must try: the Trout!
author: Jac J.

description: The restaurant is located in a nice neighborhood and serves good food. I've been going here for over two years and I always get the roast beef hash. It's really good, portions are large and food comes out fast. The last time I visited though, I decided to try something new, I ordered the pesto chicken sandwich. I was not impressed, the sandwich felt like something I could easily cook at home. The fies that came with it were good and crisp. It's rather cheap and it won't break your piggy bank. It's a good restaurant where I like to go with friends and catch up on our lives and where you can take your parents to if you want something simple and fast.
author: Jenna T.

description:
This is a solid four star Brunch and Breakfast place. The crepes are a must try! The egg benedicts are delicious. The potatoes are seasoned to perfection. Not the stellar 5 star coffee, but good. Also, they have a small cozy patio area to enjoy the afternoon sun.

The service here is outstanding. My friend (non-Yelper) and I dined at Savor on a sunny day when they had a few open tables in the patio. He wanted to be in the sun and I wanted to be in the shade. I gave in and the host sat us at a sun glaring table. My friend forgot his sunglasses, so we asked to be moved over to a shady area. He was too cold, so we once again moved over to a table that was shady on my side and sunny on his. Pure bliss! The waiter was extremely patient with our 3 Little Bear Escapade and still full of smiles.

Good food, great service, wonderful atmosphere, and won't break the bank.
author: Liz K.

description:
Yum.E. Breakfast /Brunch spot 

Amazing soy chorizo omelet and my roommate devoured her tofu scramble. 

Totally worth the trip way out in the BFE, otherwise known as Noe Valley.
author: LisaMarie C.

description:
I've been a big fan of Savor for years now. Their menu consists of mostly savory crepes, sandwiches, huge salads, and some yummy breakfast items. 

The restaurant itself is casual and laid back, and you won't have trouble getting a table unless it's brunch, and then you will definitely have to wait, which is the biggest drawback along with sometimes tough parking.

My recommendations are the Tuscany crepe (sooooo good), or if you are there for brunch, the cote d'azur (eggs benedict with salmon and spinach),or if you're in the mood for a salad the grenada.. It's totally one of my favorite places in the neighborhood.
author: Ashley H.

description:
Delicious sandwiches come with mixed greens and browned potatoes (that don't leave you feeling depressingly sick and mournful like fries do). A nice courtyard out back with Christmas-light lit trees. If only parking was this cozy.

Only accepts Visa and Mastercard.
author: Keane L.

description:
My dear friend Marissa took me here for my birthday dinner--I couldn't believe I'd not been here before!  

Because I was starving (not only am I getting lovelier with age, I am also getting hungrier, apparently!) and too many things looked good, I opted for the small Athena salad--which was one of many interesting choices but not a stand-out in terms of freshness, a cup of one of the better black bean chili soups I've had (just say yes to the sour cream!), and shared the trout and spinach that was recommended by our waiter. The trout was very good, though I hate when the menu doesn't say when fish is breaded. 

We had stellar service--seated right away and checked on frequently. The decor is warm and french-feeling, and I can definitely see going back for the brunch and sitting on the back outdoor patio. The eggs and omlette menu looked so good, as a matter of fact, I wished I had a hang over just so I could try it.

A whole star docked for the really poor wine selection. If your favorite wino Gretchen P. can't find a single drinkable wine on the list, you might consider starting to prepare for the apocalypse. Or at least a blue moon. So if that was you pointing and mocking me with my cup of chamomile tea, bite me--it was not because I am all old and shite now, it was sheer lack of choices! I will keg stand your face into the ground!
author: Gretchen T.

description: Savor is so nice to vegetarians (the "Arizona" omlette is made with soy bean chorizo!).  Yes, the wait is long.  But they give you free coffee while you're waiting and the waitstaff is super nice.  I've only ever been for brunch, but I've had consistently good food and HUGE portions. I always leave happy.
author: Cassidy P.

description:
I was starving and so was craving a place just like this.  I wanted a place that provided all the breakfast options and then some.  I got a savory crepe that had sun dried tomatoes, pesto and grilled chicken.  In addition, there were potatoes and mixed greens.  I also got a fruit salad.  The waiter was super attentive and kind.  One star off because I could taste what seemed to be a soap residue on the fruit slices (probably from the cutting board).  Also, my mocha was slightly too sweet.
We were seated right away so long as we didn't mind sitting inside.
author: Lauren S.

description:
A fantastic find in one of my favorite neighborhoods in SF. The last time I ate there was with two girlfriends to celebrate a birthday. We ordered one of the appetizer specials...a prawn-avocado-tomato-cilantro ceviche that was fantastic. The salads were fresh and reasonably priced. 

If you are looking for a low-key evening in one of the quieter SF neighborhoods, Savor is a great option.
author: Jenn G.

description: Ate lunch there yesterday and had a most delicious and plentiful salad.  Every time I go there, the service and the food knock me out!  It has a comfortable atmosphere with lots of light and the patio which doesn't pile parties on top of each other.  Someday, I'm going to have to go for dinner and experience something sublime, I'm sure
author: Mary D.

description:
Fab brunch in Noe's cute restaurant/bar area on 24th.  GREAT satisfying food for those who love a hearty brunch.  Nice ambiance.  Delicious walnut raisin French toast is ginormous and can be shared (6 fluffy half slices of bread; actually just found out you can do a half order even though it's not on the menu).  Salmon benedict dish is also yummmmm.  

The wkend wait is not too bad (10-20 min) but keep proactive checking with the hosts.  Savor has a good number of tables since there's also an outdoor patio.  Service was pretty good although they mixed up our drinks order and only brought water to the person who asked.
author: Chris P.

description:
Savor is along the lines of what I think of as standard San Francisco food.   Mix of various American standard items, some influenced by other cuisines, but really not being much of one or the other.  Chances are that you order anything at Savor, it won't be authentic anything but authentic San Francisco.

I've been here twice, most recently for the post-bookclub-dinner.  I ordered the eggs benedict with salmon (I believe it was called Cote d'Azur...this is what I mean, the pretensions to cuisine influence from elsewhere but really, it's just eggs benedict with salmon).  In my opinion, it's preferable to have something on the salty side topping your eggs benedict because the hollandaise sauce and the eggs are so mild.  So, I would have liked the salmon to be smoked salmon...but alas, it was rather bland salmon.  

As other people have noted, portions are very very large here.  All of our plates were plenty full.

I do give them kudos for serving breakfast til closing time (I love being able to order breakfast any time of the day).  And our waitress seemed friendly enough.  But both times, there's been nothing that struck me as particularly special about the place.  Good neighborhood joint, and a decent enough place if you are looking for a place to eat in Noe Valley...but not a destination spot by any means.
author: Sooj O.

description:
The Riviera crepes here made my life.

The fresh bananas, strawberries and warm nutella in that sweet crepe worked in perfect harmony to make my nip-er, taste buds- explode with delight! 

Having already had my life made, I felt secure in branching out to try a savory crepe on my next visit. The Tuscany transformed this life-long mushroom avoider into a believer. And as for the accompanying heaps of season potatoes and well dressed salad... *orgasmic shudder*

Need I say more?
author: Katherine E.

description:
Today I enjoyed Sunday brunch with my husband.  Before ordering our meals we get the Spicy Cornbread with Jalapeno Jelly.  On their menu, it is described as "a must" and this is so true.  There are 2 slices of cornbread served with an orange colored marmalade with minced jalapenos.  The jelly is sweet with a hint of spicy - very unique and tasty.

I ordered the Provence Egg Scramble, which is served with salmon, spinach, onions and goat cheese.  This scramble is on the rich side (the way I like it) and is very delicious.  With it, I had their roasted rosemary potatoes and sourdough toast.  I only ate half my potatoes since the scramble was large in portion.  The sourdough toast is a thicker slice of bread best enjoyed with their raspberry jelly.

My husband ordered the Tuscany Crepe with chicken, mushrooms, garlic, tomatoes, pesto, almonds and Parmesan cheese.  With his crepe, he gets rosemary potatoes and a salad.  The crepe is a pretty good size and very flavorful - a favorite of his!

For drinks, we both ordered mango iced teas.  This is a very good tea which is light and refreshing.  Since it's flavored, no sugar is needed.  All waitstaff are very friendly and casual which is a big plus!

At Savor, you have a choice of dining indoors or dining on the patio.  A couple of tips:
1.  The place can be busy during brunch hours.  For those that like to avoid larger crowds, the place relaxes after 2PM.
2.  Noe Valley parking is a bear! (Public transit, taxi or riding a motorcycle are good alternatives).

This is one of my favorite places for brunch in San Francisco.
author: Janet H.

description:
When my mom suggested this place, I was initially a little bit wary.  From the outside, it looked like a Crepevine ripoff Noe Valley style.  I was expecting to pay a bunch of money for a crepe I could get at Bean Bag for the same price--but with twice as much crepe.

Well, I was wrong, and maybe I'm a little too judgmental of places like Noe Valley.  OK, that last statement was a little strong, but I was wrong about Savor, so let me elaborate.

It's not like Crepevine at all.  It's an actual sit-down restaurant, which it doesn't look like it will be from the outside.  (OK, so I missed the gigantic PLEASE WAIT TO BE SEATED sign.)  There are some nice tables inside, but the best ones are in the little patio out back.  The service was attentive, and the menu is pretty extensive.

I had the Kyoto crepe, and it was really good.  What I was really impressed by, though, was the size of the crepe and the amount of salad and home fries that came with it.  My mom's French dip was also pretty substantial.

So it's not overpriced at all, and I felt like I was actually getting a deal--something that rarely happens at a non-taqueria in San Francisco.
author: John S.

description: Kid friendly. Great for breakfast.  A little trouble poaching an egg, though;-). Good coffee and great service.
author: Avi G.

description:
I like Savor, I really do, so it might sound bad when I say that it is one of my default restaurants. What I mean is, Savor is like Crepevine and Squat and Gobble, where you go there because everyone in your group is undecided, you're tired of debating, and you know that everyone can get something that will satisfy their craving. Portions are large, dishes cater to vegetarians, and the meals are decently priced. 

I would definitely recommend coming here if your parents and siblings are visiting you from out of town, simply because the menu isn't too creative (or intimidating) for those timid tasters. 

For me, Savor is my comfort food. Not in the traditional sense of "comfort food," but in the sense that it always makes me feel nice an full on a Sunday afternoon.
author: Laura G.

description: I came here with Laura P. when I was in town visiting her, and I loved it! We shared a salad and each had a cup of the vegetarian chili. YUM the chili was so good more like TeX Mex style black beans then chili but very good none the less. We also split a bottle of champagne that came at the very reasonable price of $14 ( it was good too!).
author: Jessica M.

description:
I am still thinking about the crepe I had there and it has been almost two weeks now. I wish we lived near Savor. The patio setting was perfect for our day in SF. I had the best crepe since being in Paris! The crepe itself was crunchy yet soft, the inside was a mixture of pesto, sun dried tomatoes and chicken that was so yummy! My Hubby had the Mexican one and mama had the salmon one that looked really good as well. 
Our service was fast and friendly, something so missed while dining in most of PDX, it totally made us homesick. 
It could not have been a more perfect dining experience.
author: Karen E.

description: BIG meals, decent-enough breakfasts with vegetarian fare, so-so salads, and really amazing cornbread with jalapeno jelly: yum! Weekends mean a line out the front. Other days are a-okay. But, I wouldn't go here for anything but the cornbread.
author: Heather S.

description: I see some mixed reviews & I will admit to being an out-of-towner, but  a foodie nevertheless, who is in & out of the Bay Area regularly. We thought this place outstanding!  Not living in the Bay, we still have sticker shock when dining out there, but we thought the prices, especially for dinner, were extraordinarily reasonable for SF, and the amount of food you get for it is, again, amazing for SF.  We each had a salad so I can't comment on their regular entrees, but for someone with food tolerance issues, I could see I had a wide variety of choices, from sandwiches to crepes to more salads, when we return.  That's just the food.  I'm all about service & they were outstanding; attentive, friendly, checking back.  Tim was putting his leftover salad in a box & the bus person stopped & said, let me do that.  Small things but made our experience one I've already told many people about. Ignore those nay sayers & check this amazing food out!
author: Maureen B.

description:
Savor has resolved the age old question of, "Which came first - the chicken or the egg?"

Their response, "They come simultaneously in the same crappy, weird-ass omelet."

And their french toast is dry.  And their service is mediocre.  This is one of the most overrated restaurants in San Francisco.  Chicken in eggs?  WTF?
author: Paul B.

description:
The good:

-Lots of options
-Great back patio

The bad:
-Our server was non-existent. We only saw him when he took our order and gave us the check. And we were there when it was not that busy. 
-Huge, obscene portions 
-Food is mediocre

The ugly truth: 
-There are better options within walking distance
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description:
I went to Savor with a group of friends, and was definitely pleased. A short wait, for a group of five, gave us plenty of time to walk down the block and stop into some really neat shops.

The service was great, we had a really great waiter who was friendly and constantly checked on us. 

The menu has an array of sweet and savory. For those who like both, sharing is not a problem, as the portions are enough to share around and still get your own fix. The crepes are amazing, the potatoes too. The mimosas are well worth it too, especially if you like getting the most alcohol for your dollar.

More than just the food, the atmosphere is awesome. I recommend eating outside, a bit chilly in the shade, but otherwise a pleasant experience.
author: Mace M.

description:
The wait was long (though the free coffee does fortify your patience a lot) and the food was...ok.  Underwhelming.  I forget the name of the crepe I ordered(San Juan, maybe?).  And I wasn't alone.  Everyone in our little group complained of underwhelming, overpriced food. 

On the plus side the place has nice atmosphere.  

With Miss Millie's out of the picture and this unimpressive experience at Savor (is it SAY vur or Suh VORE?) it seems to me that Noe Valley is losing it's Brunch market share.
author: Chris S.

description:
I ate here this last Wednesday and I got food poisoning, first time EVER!  
I had the Tuscany crepe with tofu.  Aside from that the food was decent, but I've had better crepes at Crepes a-go-go.
author: Molly M.

description:
I have always loved Savor.  I was first here over 5 years ago and have always been impressed with their quality and their consistency over time.  The best place to sit is in the nice appointed back patio, which is very welcoming to small, well-behaved dogs, since it is accessible through a side alley.  Perfect for Lola!

The cornbread with the jalapeno jelly is TDF!  Worth coming just for that!

The New Orleans style eggs Benedict are amazing with two poached eggs on top of two crab cakes on top of an English muffin and dressed with a great holandaise sauce and served with their home fries.

The french toast made of  their home made bread is TDF.

Lola had a huge grilled ground beef patty.  Life is good!
author: A P.

description: Savor is good for Noe Valley. Big portions, fresh ingredients. Egg dishes and crepes and mimosas. The coffee is just okay. The patio is nice on warm days and there is a fireplace inside. There is typically a wait but the service is quick and good. Their sandwiches are good due to the fact that their bread is fairly amazing, really thick and fresh. Good place for a nice, simple brunch, although a little on the pricey side.
author: Jessica C.

description: Fantastic food and a top notch staff! There worth every penny
author: Creepyfly G.

description:
One of the few Noe Valley restaurants where I can maintain my four-star recommendation. If you haven't tried Savor, get over there now. The menu has changed a bit since my last review, and although a few of my favorites are gone (which ALWAYS happens), the replacements are just as tasty. 

I didn't mention the salads in my last review. I think I've tried every salad on the menu. I don't recall being disappointed once, and I am certainly able to remember when salad disappoints. So as long as you stay away from the gooey dessert crepes, this is a great heart-healthy way to spend your evening (or Sunday brunch!).
author: Daniel C.

description:
Yum! Hell Yeah, bring it on!

Breakfast at 2:00pm, totally my style. Had a mean craving for Huevos Rancheros. The Coronado Omelette hit the spot. 

Nice strong coffee, Capricorn (note to self). Great service, totally fun and energetic server. The outdoor area looks lovely as well.

Will I be back? I sure as hell hope so!
author: alexa c.

description:
How does this place only have 3.5 stars? That makes no sense to me. 

I've come to Savor on several occasions and have yet to be disappointed. Their menu provides more diversity and options than most brunch places in SF, and each dish is well prepared. Staples include the Pumpkin Spics Pancakes, and some of the crepe dishes (especially with the chicken apple sausage). I've never had to wait an excessive amount of time, which is wonderful. 

I plan to continue frequenting Savor, as it's one of my favorite brunch places in SF.
author: William d.

description:
cooking is executed twice a year. christmas and thanksgiving. it's done perfectly with compliments as tips. For brunch? savor. it can be a bit of a wait. parking can be a nightmare. but it's well worth the hoop jumping.

pumpkin pancakes and bloody marys
-fluffy, tasty, savory, sweet, can't get enough, mouth watering, craving it as I type & a cure for a hang over.

service was the best. our waitress was on top of our shit, kept it real and was quite a looker. the host and other staff was great too. very accommodating and assured a comfortable eating experience for me and my friend.

cooking? not today. or any of the 362 days. thank you savor, your bloody mary's are stronger than extra strength advil.
author: Alex C.

description: Great food, great atmosphere, outdoor seating, you must try the JALAPEÑO CORNBREAD. It's awesome!!!
author: Raul M.

description: I like Savor, but I don't get why people wait up to an hour to eat brunch here.  I think it's best to come during off hours when it's less crazy.  I usually get a salad--the Sonoma is excellent.  Today I got the tuna melt and the middle of the tuna was still cold, but I guess it was nice that there was a lot of tuna.  Sometimes with brunchy kind of places, I think about how I could make a lot of the stuff at home, but I think they do crepes better than I could.  They're sort of a big deal--like very prettily done.  The servers here are way nicer than most places, so that is a good thing.  There is this one server guy who has seriously the most ripped legs, it's sort of distracting.  He must do a lot of leg presses!
author: Julia D.

description:
Staff:   Rude, rushed, pushy and annoying.

"Could you read the menu and order quickly, please?"

Oh, yeah, right on it.

Hair in the yogurt/cucumber salad that accompanies the Cyprus crepe.. Pissy attitude about it --- no apology.

Tried to remove plates twice before we were done eating.

Thanks for ruining a $40 outdoor lunch on a sunny day.

Beware: waiter with braided ponytail.  

Bottom line: Awfully unfriendly staff.
author: Tony S.

description: I had the Jamaican Crepe here and it was excellent.  Others in my group got the pancakes.  Those servings were huge!  This is a great places for breakfast any time of day.  Also, the service is wonderful and the atmosphere is just what you'd expect for a place on 24th street.  I was just visiting San Francisco, but when I get back, I'll certainly have to hit Savor!
author: Aaron D.

description: An always reliable spot. Go early, before the crowds come.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Grade: B+

Very cute place! Loved the crepes there, though I've had better in the Japan town area in SF. Great place for brunch with friends.
author: Lisa N.

description:
I think brunch is the most important meal of Sunday...or any day that you can have it, so I love any place that does it well.  This place is usually packed, but well worth it.  We would walk up the big hill on 24th and wait outside in the sun, which I really can't complain too much about.  

I always had good service and I like their little courtyard patio.  I like their menu of crepes, but I don't think I could ever stray from the french toast.
author: Elizabeth W.

description:
Savor is BY FAR my favorite lunch spot on 24th.  The staff is friendly and simply good.  The crepes are savory delicious, so many different flavors and combinations to choose from, and they actually make you feel like you're eating a healthy lunch with a small salad on the side.  

The salads entrees are the BEST ever!  About 6 or so to choose from and every single one of them is a healthy treat!  For a few dollars more you can even add chicken or salmon to the salad.  For about $11 you can have a giant salad with perfectly grilled salmon on top!  

Only down side - you will definitely wait for a table - but I guess that's an indication that I'm not the only one who is a big fan of this savory goodness!
author: Elaine G.

description:
I came here for breakfast with my family on my birthday since my brother was visitng from Mexico. My older sisters friend is actually a resident a couple blocks away from this restaurant and she is the one who suggested we go there. 

The place is a bit small when you come in, but there is outside seating in the back, and a little more space once you walk to the back of the place. The customer service is great, or at least i thought so, for them being as busy as they were on the day that we went, and at the time of day, it sure was a lot better service than I have gotten in other restaurants.

They have lots of options, it was hard for me to choose any one thing to eat, and the portions being so big, I had to take much of mine home, which is great I love leftovers! I would definetly recommend coming here and enjoying the nice atmosphere.
author: Rosie S.

description:
This is my single most favorite restaurant in this neighborhood. They have your standard SF crepe fare, but then they expand from that with some great brunch dishes, like my all time favorite (for here), the "New Orleans" flavor of eggs benedict. Amazingly flavorful sauce, if a bit too thick. The crabcakes the eggs are on are great.

I often come to this neighborhood expressly for a brunch at savor. Although, the place has been stellar every late evening I've come here for dessert and espresso.

Trust me, have the eggs benedict.
author: Dave M.

description:
I love coming here for breakfast during the week!

The crepes are great because they have a salad with them and it's hard to find a salad for breakfast anywhere.  Plus they are full of flavor from all of the interesting ingredients in the crepes. 

Service here is always always excellent.

I love being able to sit outside in the garden patio when the weather is conducive ...which is always a plus here in SF.
author: Sue U.

description:
Nothing special here
Yet Noe Valley lines up
Those silly yuppies
author: Mel H.

description:
The menu for brunch is basically Crepevine Noe Vally style.  Which means it probably costs a buck or two more but there is a nice sunny patio in the back spattered with hipsters.  No complaints, it was a nice meal.

By far the best feature offered by the Savorians is the coffee station by the door where customers who are waiting for tables can have free coffee while they wait.  I've always loved places that respect the waiting customer.  Waiting for food outside a restaurant when you're hungry and can see people inside greedily dinning on your food is maddening, especially In the morning when I'm at my grumpiest.  In this moment of weakness the fine folks at Savor got me going with an I.V. of coffee.  Well done!
author: Aaron M.

description:
This place is awesome!  I came here for Brunch with a Girlfriend recently.  The interior is really cozy and friendly.  We sat by the fireplace in the back.  The food was really good, and portions were quite large.  The Bloody Mary was tasty.  I ordered the mexican avocado and cheese omelette., which was yummy.  She got one of the many benedicts on the menu and was very happy as well.  This is the kind of place you want to eat, kick back, drink some cocktails and enjoy the morning.

We will come here again for sure!
author: Corey L.

description:
Don't really understand the hype (or the constant line out the door).  Pretty unmemorable - not great, not bad.  But certainly not worth the wait.
The best feature of Savor is the private patio in the back.

UPDATE:  I take it back.  This place is good.  Oh, man, it's good.  Dammit! I'm one of the minions!

****UPDATE #2

I
Love
This
Place
.
author: Christine M.

description:
Love Savor... I go there with friends, on dates or by myself. The food is great and the staff is friendly. They never hassle me to leave once  done eating. 

The salads (Bangkok salad esp.) are amazing and the cherry sweet crepe is to die for.
author: Soham K.

description:
Who knew that Savor had such a large dining area? Which makes it a good spot to meet friends with strollers, car seats and babies:)  

I've stopped in a couple of times and the food has been good and basic.  I've had the french toast which was a basic toast with a good cinnamon flavor.  I've also had the omelet with black beans, salsa, sour cream and avocado.  It sounded like a dream but was just ok.  I think it lacked flavor and the portion was huge. I've also tasted the New Orleans benedict and was underwhelmed by the lack of flavor.  

This is a basic breakfast place, but I heard the salads and lunches are better.  I'll be back to give the lunch menu a try soon!
author: Valarie A.

description:
great food! CRAZY large portions. 

could get loud- very family friendly (kids) and food is good.
author: Art A.

description: Very busy place but overall the food is great here.  Great for Brunch during the weekend and if it sunny enjoy the patio siting.
author: Pedro U.

description: This is the best breakfast place in Noe Valley.  For $11 you get a fantastic breakfast.  You can find me at Savor every Saturday morning, loving the food and the coffee on the outside patio.  Truely this place is fantastic.
author: Ethan W.

description:
Go to Savor about 30 minutes before you think your tummy is going to need food on the weekend. You can put your name in and go check out some nearby stores on 24th.  Great menu selection for all types of tastes and cravings. Friendly & speedy service. Average price is approx. $10-$15 per person.

I like Savor because you can see the cooks making the food right behind the counter, and for some reason this makes me feel like I am a guest in their home. 

If you are getting brunch. The pancakes are sinfully good & you cannot go wrong with the scrambles. If you are debating whether or not you should have a coffee, I recommend you do so. It's good.
author: Megan M.

description:
What a wonderful place. 

We sat outside (beautiful day) and enjoyed the sun. I loved the little courtyard with the tree in the middle. 

I also loved the $5 Mimosas. 

The menu had so many choices, all that looked amazing so I knew I was at a good place! 

I ordered a Greek salad as we had decided on a banana, strawberry, nutella, and ice cream crepe for desert so I was saving room. My guests had a tuna melt (delicious) and a chicken pesto crepe (a little too much pesto). 

The desert was a perfect finish and the service was just fine. 

The $1 tax is annoying, but thanks to yelp I was prepared. I was also charged it in SF later that night at Yebbies.
author: Vanessa y.

description:
What a cool joint!  I really enjoyed the Smoked Salmon Benedict except for one thing; the heat of the eggs actually cooked the smoked salmon in the middle, which made it not as tasty.  I can't think of any way around this, so I'll live. :)

The bloody mary was.. ODD.  I would not order it again.  But it was fairly priced and a good size glass.  The patio area is nice and sunny, and the tables just big enough for three people (not four) to spread their food out on.

I disliked the 30 minute wait, and the service was slow at best, but the server was friendly and the food tasty, so 4/5.
author: Alex C.

description:
They have a deck, and the omelettes are good, and good-sized. I'd say this place merit a satisfactory to good. Won't ever be my first brunch choice but I'm not unhappy when we end up here.

Not exactly a ringing endorsement I know. Good. Not spectacular.

They do have a patio, and it' protected from the wind.
author: Karsten P.

description: I was so happy to discover this european-style restaurant tucked away in Noe Valley- the best kept secret in San Francisco as neighborhoods go. I think it was on the same day that I actually discovered how to get to Noe Valley. Savor has become my favorite crepe place in the City. Try the Tuscany Chicken Crepe, which is filled with chunks of herbed chicken breast, sun dried tomatoes, pinenuts and cheese.  You really can't go wrong with any of the crepes here, including some very good dessert crepes, and the breakfasts are excellent as well.  There is a delightful outdoor patio seating area to the rear of the restaurant that is very nice on a sunny day, certainly more common here on the easterly flanks of Twin Peaks than in some other parts of the City.  You will have to wait in line though, as its as popular as Noe gets.
author: Rick H.

description:
Good brunch spot with some good egg dishes and lots of different crepes on the menu.  The wait staff is friendly.  And they served me what might be the biggest mimosa I've ever had.

The cornbread with jalapeno jelly: me likey.
author: Andrew E.

description:
Wow is all I can say is wow ...

I really like this place.  If only I lived closer, but several experiences later is now my favorite place to eat Breakfast in Noe Valley (where I have cat sat for a co-worker).  There are lots of great options in the area, but definitely worth a visit!
author: Anne K.

description: Yummy.  Had my first-ever Pear muffin and it was delicious.  Much better than Mama's, IMHO.
author: Angela R.

description:
If you enjoy Crepvine (chain) which I do and I can appreciate a good tasteful crepe then you will love SAVOR! Oh yes you will. If you prefer to dine out you have a choice once you arrive (if its not too busy) to eat indoors or outdoors. Cute patio outside and good service. 

I love the pesto chicken crepe (a little pricey than Crepevine)!!!
author: Ana A.

description:
The food was very good. Maybe even excellent. Very veggie friendly and super large portions. The Milan crepe or the Arizona omelette are top choices. Service was also friendly, helpful and prompt. 

Deduct one star because... Why is it so hard to get a table for more than 4 people in this city? This is a pretty big place and had plenty of tables open, but to seat 6 of us took a good 30 minutes of waiting at the least.
author: aaron f.

description:
Out with fellow Yelper and found this place by accident. The menu looked great, and smelled nice from the outside. I ordered a Club Sandwich, something simple and very difficult to screw up. It's not that I didn't trust them, but this place had a sort of "upscale" feel (Noe Valley written all over it), and I wanted to see their take on one of my all-time fav's. 

Very nice presentation, not that I care much, but it was accompanied with a rather dry salad (must've forgot my dressing because Jessica had hers), and fried potatoes, which were deliciously prepared, just like mom's! Sandwich was tasty. I wouldn't say "I loved it," but it was good enough for me to bring others for another early dinner. 

Service was really good with our waitress putting up with one of us *clears throat* not being able to decide, and returning in a timely fashion to check on us. There's a nice outdoor patio section in the back where you can seat under heating lamps or under a huge tree area. And there's plenty of space, although close enough to wonder what the old couple next to you are arguing about. The inside looks clean and organized and the staff were very friendly. 

Cheers, SF
author: Tekk A.

description:
YUM! Crepes are the best!  That is if they are done right!  And Savor for surely delivers!  

I had an ex recommend this place for breakfast, and trusted the recommendation as he has spent some quantifiable time living in France (home of authentic crepes).  I'm always up for new and improved ways to enjoy breakfast foods, and Savor was able to deliver just that.

The menu is quite extensive, but not overwhelmingly so.  Just enough choices to get your mind battling between two or three choices.  And for those people who don't care for crepes, many other traditional breakfast choices are available.  I went once with my sister in-law and she had eggs benedict with crab cakes and said they were delicious indeed!

Two crepes in my opinion stand out above the rest: the Tuscan Crepe (a delicious combination of pesto, diced chicken breast, sun-dried tomatoes, parmesan cheese, and toasted pine nuts makes for a PERFECT combination in your mouth).  The crunch that the nuts provide put this dish over the top.  The second crepe to bare mention is the Crepe Le Delice (a gooey mixture of cheddar cheeses with simple yet amazingly delicious caramelized onions is pure bliss in a bite).  Crepes are also served with golden brown country potatoes and a side salad (and interesting addition to breakfast, but one that has turned out to be quite tasty).

Although there are crowds often waiting outside for a table, if your party is smaller than 3 you often never have to wait for a table. Dessert crepes available too!  Check it out!
author: Ryan H.

description: I have been patronizing Savor for years and figured I should finally write a review.  It is my favorite spot in Noe Valley.  They have the best savory crepes and scrumptious sandwiches served along with fresh greens or hearty potatoes.  Service is usually very good.  The patio in the back is charming and if it is rainy, the inside is cozy with its open fire grill.  This is my go-to place for lunches with out-of-towners who want to check out a cool, non-touristy neighborhood.  BTW, just blocks away on 22nd between Vicksburg and Church is one of the steepest streets in the city.   Of course, I also go with my local friends.
author: Mimi C.

description:
All the good things you read about Savor are true and then some. 

On atmosphere: always warm and inviting even when packed. my favorite seat is next to the fireplace on foggy mornings like today. They recently added an awesome canopy and overhead heaters outside which feels like a relaxing outdoor reception - great addition and upgrade from the previous exposed plastic furniture fare. 

On food: Their portions are a bit ridiculous for any appetite, but that doesn't stop me from feasting til the plate shines clean. I have actually taken to requesting my savory crepes with 1/2 the filling and still feel the price is reasonable given all the house potatoes and salad that come with virtually every dish. 

They have also been accommodating for this 'tired-of-tofu-and-mushrooms-vegetarian.' Today I brunched on eggs over easy, english muffin, house potatoes and a plate of sauteed spinach, mushroom, onions, peppers, yellow squash, and zucchini. My self-directed 'Americano' on the eggs list. 

Some other recommendations: any of their benedictions - great hollandaise and perfectly poached eggs. Cornbread slices with jalapeno jelly - a well articulated sweet and savory delight with a little kick to whet the appetite! 

Overall: Very tasty, always fast, the service is always friendly, attentive, and quick to check-in without hovering. Savor has been for years and remains for years to come my comfort food short-lister!
author: Ennis O.

description: Is this the same restaurant as Crepevine, just with a different name?  I believe it is.  Menus are identical, and the food is consistently tasty.  Even though I try to be adventurous, I inevitably end up back at my favorites - the Bangkok salad or the chicken schwarma.  Interestingly enough, I have never had a crepe here.  On a cool Saturday for brunch, in a party of 4, we were able to sit on the back patio with no wait.  The back patio is awesome - heating lamps and dogs allowed!  Indoor seating is somewhat limited.  Service is sluggish, but attentive.  Great location on 24th right in the heart of Noe.  If you venture off 24th, parking is plentiful.  Overall, a solid place for brunch/lunch.
author: Jenna C.

description:
Ok, get here before noon on a Sunday and you get seated in 5 minutes if your party is smaller then 6.

I struggled for what seemed like hours between the pancakes, the omelettes, the sandwiches and the crepes.  I have decision making issues when it comes to good food.  Especially if you can smell it cooking and you feel your stomach start to cave in on itself from the long wait for the 24 Divisidero to get to Noe Valley.

In reality, Noe Valley isn't too far from where i live, there just happens to be a gigantic hill between me and Savor and what has kept me away for so long.

We were lucky that Popeye's wasn't open as while we were waiting for the bus, I was tempted to run in and get biscuit appetizers for us.

I finally made a decision, last minute, before I can stop myself, I said "PAN-CAKE" even though my mind was made up to get an omelette, because you get a bagel with your egg dish and this has been one of the only places that tells you you have a choice between bagel or toast and doesn't charge you a ridiculous additional dollar for it.

But I said it like a starving, drool faced 5 year old.  "PAAAN-CAAAAKE."

And they were the fluffiest and bestest panckes I had ever had.
author: Jen I.

description:
After so many years, this is still one the great old standbys of brunching. Even as the clientele and neighborhood demographic have changed, it's still a staple, and for good reason.

Even if you're not a crepe fan, you can still find some tasty items on the menu here at Savor. (Just be prepared to wait for a table on a nice day.) I've had the San Francisco crepe quite a few times, and it's always served with a healthy portion of salmon and other goodies. The included salad is quite tasty and you get way too many potatoes. 

Service can be hit or miss depending on who you get, but more likely than not they're super friendly and pretty quick.
author: Aaron L.

description:
I'm somewhere between a three and a four star rating on this place.  I'm leaning towards 3 right now, but I intend on returning to make my final decision.  

I really liked the cornbread.  The menu actually says on it that its a "must."  They were right.  Very tasty.

I had the New Orleans - a benedict with crab cakes, poached eggs, and a cajun hollandaise sauce on an english muffin.  Extremely filling and pretty good. The potatoes were good too - not to die for, but good.  

I enjoyed my very large mimosa thoroughly.  Get one!
author: Angie C.

description:
Met some friends here for lunch one day.  Another crepe place.  We sat in the beautiful courtyard and I ordered the Tuscany crepe (chicken, mushroom, garlic, sundried tomatoes and pesto) and a mango ice tea.  So delicious!  Service was fast and they were crazy busy.
One less star for the parking sitch.  Of course,  parking all over the city is always a bugger.  But I usually possess the sought after parking chi that got me great parking in the Mish and right in front of a karaoke bar in Japantown... so I'm rarely a victim of the neverending block circling that is so popular there, eh?
author: Joie P.

description: I love Savor.  The food is very good (I love the crepe choices, especially the Mazatlan!).  The atmosphere is very friendly and welcoming with good service - attentive and not rushed.  Though a recent discovery, I have gone back 3 times and consider Savor to be a SF favorite.  It is a great place to go if you want to relax and talk while eating great food (there are a lot of choices that would accommodate just about any diet).
author: Michelle I.

description:
This restaurant should pay me for how much I personally promote this place!

Hands down the best bfast in the city! If you are hung over or just hung dizzle this place will fill your belly and put a smile on your groggy face. The portions are huge and so fresh and innovative. I usually order the santa fe crepe that comes with chicken apple sausage, provolone, salsa and scrambled eggs, with yummy potatoes and a side salad for around $10! 

The service is always pretty good, they seem to be growing more busy every time I go there so you do have to wait a little. But its so worth it!!! So worth the wait and so worth the trek to Noe Valley. And while you wait for your meal, Id also recommend getting the cornbread with jalapeno jelly :)
author: Heather S.

description:
Mimosas Mimosas Mimosas! There are two reasons to get mimosas at Savor. 
1. Because they are amazingly good 
2. Because the service is so bad, you have no choice but to drink....and drink....and drink

The food here is pretty good too. The cornbread is AWSOME!! 

Recap: when going to Savor get the cornbread and mimosas
author: Chris P.

description: Maybe we came here on a bad day...but the service was horrible and so so slow. The savory crepes were ok, but the dessert crepe - the crepe itself was so cooked that it was hard and crispy. I couldn't cut the crepe. Blah.
author: Carol L.

description:
It's right in my 'hood.
Loathe the mediocrity.
Love the convenience.
author: Alana D.

description:
This place is really worth the wait!

Why?

- Lots of space, beautiful ambiance and awesome additional outdoor seating

- friendly, attentive and flirty waitstaff (never had so much fun waiting in line to use the bathroom!)

- Lots of choices.  The menu's KING size and you can really splurge on a ton of stuff if you're in the mood.  They have a wide selection of sweet and savory crepes on top of the standard brunch options

- GR8888888T food!  The cornbread with jalopeno sauce is especially good.  

- Portion size is HUGE, you definately get a bang for your buck

- Can eat like a mo'fo' and walk home (if you live in Noe Valley, the Mission or Castro).  Eases the guilt of overeating...
author: Swetha G.

description:
Really good variety for a breakfast place. You will have to wait on the weekends, but if you coming with a few people then I am sure everyone will find something that they want.

If I could give it 3.5 I would, because I think Brenda's is better. This place is better for a more standard breakfast joint.
author: Sophia D.

description:
When I lived in Noe Valley, I never ate here more than a handful of times. I  think it was because they always seemed to be very busy and crowded, and would wind up seating us in the outback, where it was cold. 

Garden dining has it's place, but the cool San Francisco weather never made me a fan of it. The crepes are what we usually came here for, and Savor does not disappoint. Tasty food, in pretty large portions if I remember right. The iced tea was fruity flavored though (mango?), which I remember disliking here.

The thing that always makes me wonder is if the name of the restaurant is pronounced as in 'favor,' or in a mangling of the French, 'savoir.' The latter seems altogether too popular.
author: Milk and Cheese ..

description:
Had a casual lunch here with some friends.  We came in at around noon on a Monday & it appeared we just beat the lunch rush.  I was so hungry that I forgot to take a picture of my food before I dug in.  I never do that!

I had the delice crepe with added ham...it was pretty tasty!  I saw another review on here likening Savor's crepes to ones the yelper had in Paris...and I have to agree!  I spent part of this summer living in Paris, & my crepe with sweet onion, cheese, & ham definitely reminded me of the ones I had there (the only thing missing was the oeufs!)  

My friend had a sweet crepe and her's looked delicious.  They all come with a generous portion of delicious whipped cream and vanilla ice cream.  I think I want a sweet crepe next time!

I'll definitely stop by here again the next time I'm in the city.
author: Katrina V.

description: Try the spicy corn bread!!! Amazing sauce! yum!
author: Carmina L.

description:
This place is pretty amazing.  The service could be a bit friendlier, but where the service lacks, the food takes over. 

AMAZING Crepes!  I've only had the crepes, but they are so delicious!  I totally recommend this place for weekend brunch also!
author: Amie B.

description: Bourgie, but friendly, brunch joint on 24th St in Noe Valley.  On sunny days their back patio is a consummate location to enjoy savory crepes and mims.  Servers and staff were standouts in terms of friendly service. Expect a 30 hr wait on weekends.
author: Sid D.

description:
Went here with friends the other day and had the best time. We went for a birthday brunch and had very generous sized mimosas for a 5.00 bargain. The food was fantatstic and huge portions- Are server has become a friend of my friends, so are service was great, he also bought dessert as for the birthday- Great patio and calm atmosphere- can't wait to go back...

P.s. Get the corn bread  and jalepeno jelly-
author: ryan H.

description:
Good yuppy Noe Valley place. Its worth a try, but I doubt I'll ever have a craving to come back. The crepes and the sandwich were good, but I think its a bit overpriced. Parking is pretty crappy in the area, the wait was a bit too long, and there was some fat kid annoying the hell out of us while we were here. Seriously, if you have a fat annoying kid with the party, sit them in the broom closet or have them shut the hell up and stop ruining it for everyone.

Suuuuuiiiiiiiii!
author: Rocky K.
Mister G.

description:
Disappointing.  There are a lot of crepe houses in San Francisco, but this is not the one to go to.  This makes me sad, though, because it's the closest one to my house.

I don't expect a lot from a crepe, but these crepes were BLAND!  I had the salmon crepe, and it had almost no flavor!  How is that possible with salmon?  Besides that, it was excessively oily and the accompanying potatoes were dry.  Not appetizing at all.  My bf's breakfast wasn't any better.

What a restaurant lacks in food, it can sometimes make up in service.  Not the case!  The service was particularly slow, and we had to hunt down our waiter to get our bill, and then give him our payment.  I'm all for slow, laid back breakfasts but this was ridiculous.  He was neither attentive nor particularly friendly.  The only saving grace was the quaint back patio.  It's always nicer to have breakfast outdoors while surrounded by foliage.

So if your looking for delicious crepes and great service, you won't find it here.
author: Vicente G.

description:
Heard a lot of good things, but wasn't very impressed.  The muffins were the best thing, but even then they were a bit dry.

I also had the Baja scrambled eggs.  They were a bit spicy as promised but not quite the flavorful "hicken apple sausage, mushrooms, spinach onions, chipotle peppers " as described on the window.

I may just be an NYC brunch snob, but I think SF can do better, and I'll be sure to go find it!
author: Evan B.

description:
