Anyone know which came first this place or Crepevine? Are they owned by the same people? The menu is so similar I could be at either place. Costa del sol Benedict? Tuscany Crepe? Jamaican sweet crepe with bananas and caramel rum sauce? 

Unfortunately overall I didn't like this place quite as much as Crepevine. 

For starters the potatoes were not very flavorful, they seemed to be boiled and lightly fried They were not burnt (which is good) and were soft (also good), but had almost no flavor. 

I liked the salad, it was on par and quite similar to crepevine. Leafy greens and a nice dressing that isn't too heavy. 

The Crepe (Tuscany) was good, it had lots of chicken and a good blend of the pesto, Parmesan and almonds. 

The Jamaican crepe was way below Crepevine though, weak sauce. 

The burger was tasty, I forget what it was called, but it was loaded with avocado, mushrooms, cheese and a fat patty. 

Bottom line: 
I wouldn't protest going back again, but I also wouldn't seek it out for another meal.
author: Stephen H.

description: I'm surprised this place isn't rated higher.  I go here at least once  a week and have for years.  The food and service are consistently good.  I've never ordered anything I didn't love/  I find it to be a great value and I love their patio.  Also, the wait here on the weekend is much shorter than other restaurants despite the long line.  If I could, I would give them a 6th star for their supersized mimosas!  Yum!
author: Mariana B.

description: Looooove this place! My boyfriend and I have gone a few times and everything we've ordered has been excellent. He usually gets breakfast and I usually go for the lunch items.
author: Elise C.

description:
I've eaten here during every meal - brunch, lunch, dinner, snack, whatever...I've been going here for over six years now and again it's one of those winners that does not disappoint.

They have a great menu selection from salads, sandwiches, etc.  Another great thing is that this place has a high retention of their wait staff, that has to say something.  Further, service is great!

Menu suggestions:  have the toasted corn bread with spicy jelly.  If you want something on the lite end the soup and salad combo is always a winner.  For brunch, it's all good *g*!
author: Tiberius A.

description: This is our go to place for a late dinner or sometimes, brunch.  The food is good and reliable.  We tried their benediction, scrambles, burger, pork chop, swedish pancake, etc.  All very good.  We are glad that Savor is open late and serves breakfast all day.  We hope it stays that way.
author: V B.

description:
Crepes and more.  The more = Breakfast at anytime.  Entrees start around $10.00 and range to about $20.00.  Crepes and Breakfast are in the lower stratosphere of $10.00.

The service was friendly and kept our water glasses filled.

What was consumed.
Santa Fe
Tuscany
There were no complaints with either and I would order them again.
author: Po L.

description:
Why five stars? Because after a leisurely hour spent here early Thanksgiving morning, I left feeling grateful, appreciated, relaxed and recharged. It's rare for a business to give that feeling to a person -- usually I am just hoping for "satisfied."

I dropped in here to kill time between an early-morning SFO dropoff and midday family Thanksgiving in the city. Still a bit groggy, I walked in at 8 a.m. shouldering a book bag and my cares of the moment. I was swiftly shown to a lovely nook right by the fireplace. The Cote d'Azur (2 poached eggs, smoked salmon) and green tea hit the spot. My server, David K, was awesome -- exactly the right level of attentiveness. He seemed to intuit that I needed a corner to disappear for a little bit before heading back out into the fray of families and last-minute Whole Foods shoppers. He didn't hurry me at all, even though I sat through three parties at his other tables.

No, it wasn't the best poached eggs I'd ever had -- that honor goes to Cafe Fanny in Berkeley. But they were quite good, and part of one of my favorite solo restaurant experiences ever.
author: Jack G.

description:
Big on crepes so I gotta love this place. Local spot near my apartment. I'd only knock it that it feels very commercial. Lacks that local SF flavor. Everything just seems very BJ's & Mimi's Cafe in there.

But the food is good. Generous portions, everyone working there is real friendly. Pricing to match.
author: Nelson C.

description:
Tasty, interesting meals made with good ingredients and served in a pleasant, bright, faux Tahoe-village setting.  The portion sizes are ample and the food feels Yuppie but is comfort-food satisfying.  Salmon and cream cheese scramble anyone?

I have liked this place for years (and cannot believe I haven't Yelped it before), but its luster grows when compared to newcomer Toast down the block.  The food here tastes, there is space between dining parties, and you don't feel like you're in a bus station.  I don't mean to damn with faint praise, but in comparison Savor should get six stars.
author: Galen W.

description:
Good Sunday brunch place to go to nurse the remnants from the night prior....and the staff knows it, so they take it easy on you. I can keep my oversized sunglasses on the entire time indoors and outdoors, without feeling uncomfortable. (Savor staff is quite aware of the rockstar lifestyle).
 I haven't found a specific dish i like here.. I think it's just the back patio that people flock to. The patio area is sunny, relaxing, and even complete with aunthentic gigantic spiderwebs, bugs & buterflies! Call ahead & put your name down, it will save much time. Afterwards, don't forget to window shop down 24th st and buy somethign random that you wil later question... Then go home and nap more.
author: Nicole L.

description:
I eat dinner here more than I eat brunch.

The food tastes good, it's cheap (for dinner), the staff are decent and the venue is pleasant enought. I can't really ask for more.
author: bristol b.

description:
Prices and food quality seem to me to have an inverse relationship here at Savor. As prices get higher the food seems to me to be less good.

I was a fan of this place in the past and well I guess I am still a fan of sorts, but I've got no real passion about it anymore. Boredom, seven year itch, I'm just not sure. Maybe they just need to shake things up a bit. New Salad maybe?

The Grenada salad has been and remains still really good.

And that's all I have to say about that.

- Forrest
author: Jack K.

description: Great breakfast option on 24th now that Millie's is closed. I enjoy going here for the sandwhiches, omlettes, and those yummy house potatos. They have a great patio that's perfect for a warm day. Plus the service is usually good and i've never had to wait.
author: Nikki M.

description:
Wow, haven't been to Savor in a long time, but I do recall going all the time a few years back.  Thanks Elaine G. for reviewing this place.
I was just thinking of this place the other day and had decided that I a re-visit was in order.
Will be sure to update this once I do.
author: Rose C R.

description: This place just misses the mark for me. Been there a couple of times and I just don't get where they're going with this place. The food is hit or miss. Honestly, I can't even provide much detail b/c they made that little of an impression on me. Yikes. Not a good sign
author: Natalie L.

description:
This was my first brunch experience in Noe Valley and it will always hold a special place in my heart. 

I really like their omelette's.
author: J-Meoww W.

description:
Ok ...Savor in the Noe Valley. What a restaurant for breakfast and brunch.
Every thing so perfect. The food, the atmosphere. It is Not expensive for the quality of food and high quality in customer service. There were a few thing that made me feel back home in brazil every single time that I eat there. Lemonade its so far the best in the bay area, the other thing that always make me come back it s the Pumpkin Jelly for a nice and sweet toast after eggs with chicken sausage. PROPS for you guys and those hard worker latinos who make that restaurant on of the top in SANFRAN ...
author: Alex M.

description: This is the 1st time we've been there. Surprised at how tiny this place looks from the outside, but once you go in, it really opens up! Parking is actually pretty decent even though it's on a busy street. We went (on a Sat or Sun - I forget) for brunch & got a nice table in under 10 minutes! Decor is really cool & they also have nice outdoor seating (with heat lamps). The food is really AMAZING - tasty & FRESH, the portions are pretty huge - especially the omelet plates with potatoes. Their bloody mary's are the best I've had in a long time & the Mimosa's just as TO DIE FOR! They run a great place here. We wanted to try so many dishes, but had to settle for choosing manageable-ish portions lol!  Even though we are in San Jose, we plan to get there more often. Staff is very friendly & everyone wants to make sure your dining experience is the best it can be!  DON'T MISS THIS truly delicious experience!! GO SAVOR!
author: S. C.

description:
Poached eggs overcooked
"Fresh" OJ ain't Odwalla
Mmm pumpkin pancakes
author: Patrick T.

description: I can't believe I haven't reviewed this place yet! Savor is a solid place to have lunch in Noe Valley, and by solid I mean the service is good, there is a large menu with items for carnivores and vegetarians, there is outdoor seating and you'll leave full without having paid too much. I would give it 3.5 stars if I could, but it's not exactly fabulous food...more like an indie Cheesecake Factory.
author: Sara W.

description:
I go here mostly for the cheap vegetarian black bean chili which is the best, the free jams and the loose chamomile and mint tea. Food is sometimes bland, but I've also had great dishes here. I like the diversity of their menu and the atmosphere.

Service is hit or miss. They are usually nice and efficient, but I won't forget this time when we were told we could not move to the table next to us because there was a party waiting. Nobody sat there until 15 minutes after, and I was fuming.

The patio in the back is also part of the attraction on a bright sunny day. If I'm meeting a friend for lunch in Noe Valley I usually recomment Savor.
author: alina m.

description: I went for dinner for the first time and just had to add that the panko breaded trout is ah-maz-ing!  order with the cliantro rice and steamed veggies.... yum-o!
author: Olivia D.

description: I'll be back! The cornbread and jalapeño jelly ALONE is worth it... Next time I will have one of their awesome crepes - but on my first visit, I needed a tofu scramble (minus the egg and onions) and a bloody mary. I'm getting hungry just thinking about it.... it was so delicious!
author: Alyssa Z.

description:
This was probably the best brunch I've had in a long time.  Based on the reviews, we weren't really expecting anything mindblowing, but the food and service were by far the best we've had during our visit to SF.

I had the crab cakes benedict with a cajun hollandaise sauce.  I told Adrian, our waiter, that I wasn't sure about the cajun sauce, and he said he would bring it along with some of the regular.  My lady had a salad and added gorgonzola, as well as some veggie chili.  Both were yummy.

We heard Adrian taking orders at a nearby table and when a customer ordered sparkling water, he also brought over a drink w/ lemon in it and told the guy he thought he might like it!  We thought that was super cool.

We have been to a bunch of tourist traps, as well as some fancy local joints, and we were starting to formulate a belief that SF just had generally bad service, but from the hostess to the waiter, everybody here was energetic, warm, and seemed happy to have us there.  This was such a welcome change.

Every bite of the benedict, by the way, was heavenly.  The crab cakes were a really rich, satisfying texture, and the eggs were PERFECTLY poached.  I was sad, but stuffed, when the meal came to an end.

This was my last mean in SF, and I have to say, it made me feel sad to leave.
author: Al F.

description: Tasty brunches here. I ordered their omelets- sausage and onions inside. Pretty good... potatoes were EXCELLENT. Coffee was average. I need to learn to stick w/ coffee from cafes! None of this average crap! Ok.. nice interior, we were seated in the back patio like area. Awesome, but I didnt appreciate being seated by the kitchen entrance at all, minus 1 star. Can get crowded so be early or a little late. Affordable.
author: Thomas L.

description: Nice place.  Good prices,  Good portions.  Weird little place.  Quirky.  I'll go back with close friends or my family when we want something simple and relaxed.  Interesting and yummy dishes.
author: Cynthia B.

description: Love Savor.  Breakfast/Brunch is fantastic but be prepared to wait.  Dinner is great too.  Very simple but yummy comfort food at night - and usually no wait.
author: Karen C.

description:
We took my in-laws here the day after Thanksgiving this year.  They were in town from the Midwest, and while we'd taken them to S.F. many times before, we'd never shown them the Noe Valley neighborhood.  Rather than doing the usual Fisherman's Wharf/China Town/Union Square route, we headed straight for 24th St.

This was our first experience with Savor, and I was a bit apprehensive after my first glance at the menu - Omelettes, Egg Scrambles, Benedictions - Oy.  Looks like I'm getting eggs...  Wait!  There are crepes and sandwiches, too!  

I decided on a sandwich - the "El Dorado" (1/2 lb of ground chunk with red onions, tomatoes lettuce and mayonnaise on a bun) - a.k.a., "hamburger."  I was very pleased with my burger, but I was actually most pleased with the sides.  The platter-sized plate came with the burger and a generous helping of a mixed green salad with a deliciously light and complimentary dressing and Savor's "home potatoes."  I really must stop for a moment and reminisce about these potatoes, as they blew the doors off any I've ever previously tasted.  Crispy and flavorful potato skins with appropriately fluffy centers - perfect!  Not too salty, not too bland.  

Everyone else at the table essentially cleaned their plates, so I assume they shared my enjoyment of their respective menu selections (a Barcelona crepe, a Baja scramble, and a Pacific sandwich).  I would definitely dine here again, and I wouldn't hesitate to recommend it to a friend looking for something a little more unique.
author: Aaron J.

description: The patio out back is very nice on a warm day, but it doesn't make up for the over-priced food.  I had the Tuscany crepe, which I thought was decent, but nothing special for $13.
author: W B.

description: Pretty darn tasty french food with gi-huge-ant portions.  My steak was goood!
author: Mas M.

description:
I've been here twice for dinner, and although the food was great both times (especially the omelet with toasted bagel on the side) I noticed that the restaurant was extermely warm and smelly inside.

I'm not talking the "Man, that's some funk! Did the bathroom flood?" type of smelly, but the smelly you get when the odor from the grill/kitchen sticks to you for the rest of the day.

The restaurant just doesn't seem to have a great ventilation system in the kitchen, which is why it gets three stars instead of four.
author: Art D.

description:
I've only been to Savor once for brunch, but absolutely loved it. It reminded me of a lot of other crepe places in the city, but with better ambiance. They had a very extensive (and creative) menu with everything from omlettes, eggs benedict variations, and crepes, to sandwichs and salads. I ordered the Santa Fe crepe with scrambled eggs, salsa, and chorizo and loved it! I know I've hit a good place when there are at least 5 things that I want to order! Choices, choices, choices! I definitely want to come back...

Helpful hint to all you complaining about the wait:
Call and put your name in before you come and your table will be ready for you when you arrive.
author: Lauren Y.

description:
First of all . . . would everyone please stop complaining about the $1 SF Health Insurance surcharge, or whatever it's called.  You're not the only one who noticed, and it's not the restaurant's fault.  Blame your mayor, your parents and Canada - everyone else does.

Anyway . . . my friend and I came here for a late lunch.  Today was a HOT day in San Francisco, so the patio was pretty full.  We ended up sitting inside by the window, so we got the benefit of the A/C and the breeze.  Just like most places in Noe Valley, Savor provides interesting people watching opportunities.

I ordered a Singapore crepe (think of a Thai chicken dish in a crepe).  The crepe was served on a giant plate with a generous serving of mixed greens salad and some home fries.  The Thai peanut sauce was a bit much for my taste, but . . . the food was very good and there was plenty of it.  It was a great value for $10.75.  The mango flavored iced tea also hit the spot.

The service was very fast and very efficient, and our waitress was easy on the eyes as well.

I will definitely be back for lunch and/or brunch - it's worth the short drive from my house in Diamond Heights.
author: Yan G.

description:
I ordered the Bangkok salad, it was perfect. Especially on a lazy afternoon in the back outdoor patio.

The salad was a great combination of curry and ginger marinated chicken breast tenders on a salad of field greens with caramalized cashews and ginger dressing.

This is a great place with lounge about and have a great lunch and conversation with friends.
author: Juan P.

description:
Myself and Savor got of to a shaky start not long after I moved here.  I was out prowling the area for early-morning grub with one of my equally un-refined buddies, and our quest took us to Savor.  Once seated, we nervously eyeballed the menu, searching in vain for the meat-and-two-eggs basics....which were nowhere to be found.  Two minutes later we were out the door heading up the street to Herb's Fine Foods ( http://www.yelp.com/biz/m9HHJIey0gqfw2fQesa3bw?hrid=yDRBHQWycb8-FYjgY-pHPg ).  Throughout the dot-com boom I'd see a wretched array of cyber-refugees from San Jose, Cupertino, and Sunnyvale line up 30 minutes deep to get in here on the weekends.  For several years, I equated Savor with needless hassle and pretentious chic...

Four years later my sidekick Tassie dragged me here kicking and screaming...and to my surprise, the post-breakfast version of Savor turned out to be a pretty cool and laid-back place! Specializing in crepes, I found the entrees to be pleasantly uncomplicated, well presented, very tasty, and surprisingly affordable!

Breakfast wise, Savor hasn't changed since the day it sent me running for cover at Herb's.  Creative Omelets, innovative "Egg Scrambles", and specially flavored pancakes sum up  the main attractions. Further down the menu are their innovative looking breakfast specialties...Creative dishes for those seeking morning chow that's off the beaten-path.  Noticeably absent are the gut-busting truck-stop specials.

Come lunchtime, the "Savory Crepes" come into the picture.  Call me a culinary idiot, but for ages I balked at this part of the menu, thinking that crepes were exclusively a desert item.  My usual choice in this department is their "Tuscany",a chicken filled crepe with mushrooms, garlic, tomatoes, and and cheese.  Also included for about ten bucks is a mixed-greens salad and a healthy-sized serving of home-fried potatoes.  I've had this about a dozen times...it's never missed the mark.

When dinnertime rolls around, crepes still dominate the menu, but an interesting number of specials and dinner plates creep into the mix.  Tassie used to get one of these all the time...and always gave it two thumbs up.  I always stuck with my tried-and-true Tuscany crepe.

Service is about optimal for a place of this type....brief, somewhat hurried, but polite and efficient.  Several good beers are on tap, and the wine selection isn't half bad either!

Peak times bring lines to Savor over the weekends.  During the week, seating is rarely if ever a problem.  A line of tables perpendicular to 24th Street goes from the reception area and past the kitchen.  Better seating (in my opinion) is available after the L-Shaped seating area makes a 90 degree turn to the right, leading to a back area that looks out over an open patio.  If possible, snag a table by the window.  Finally there's an outdoor  brick patio that's surrounded on one side by the restaurant, two sides by fences, and the back side by small shops. Ample trees and greenery make this an awesome lunch spot on a nice day.  Try to get seated in the patio if weather permits....it's what everyone else seem to do.  Come the sunshine, indoor seating at Savor usually goes begging....

I give this place two thumbs up.  The King and Queen of Jordan ate here once in the summer of 2000 ( http://www.noevalleyvoice.com/2000/July-August/king.html ) and they thought it was pretty good too!  So if you're looking for a casual place to enjoy quality food in a 24th-and-Sanchez atmosphere at 16th-and-Mission prices, follow my lead and give this place a checking out....
author: Mike W.

description:
Brunch is over-rated.  In my own humble opinion, I'd rather sleep in, and not be forced to queue up with other cranky, hungry, under-caffeinated individuals all jockeying for the same table.  I love breakfast, though, so I'm drawn to restaurants that can satisfy my need for eggs at odd hours.  Savor totally delivers, and it's just right up the street from me, so all the better.  All their egg dishes are pretty good, though I especially like the crepe with eggs, provolone, chicken apple sausage and salsa.  The potatoes are pretty good, too, though I like them best if I can manage to get them cooked a little crispy.  
All of Savor's salads are great, as well, though I'd recommend you opt for their pomegranate dressing - gives your salad an awesome, fruity kick.
author: Becca V.

description:
Always a dependable and enjoyable brunch in Noe Valley.
I won't tell you which is my favorite seat but I have one and when I am there it is definitely five star.

The portions including the mimosa are always generous and the waitstaff always effervescently warm.  I have only been for brunch but many times and recently.  The wait can sometimes be long but never during the week. They won't seat you til everyone in your party is there but they have a clamoring for tables.  Outside is not all its cracked up to be here, its almost always in the shade.  

The bathrooms are pleasant and well maintained despite their high volume of use.  Hint, there are 2 bathrooms, one is in the back tucked in near the kitchen.  You're apt to find a line for the front one and no one in the back one at all. & you;ll need the bathroom if the hefty mimosa starts your meal.
author: Sean S.

description:
I went to Savor for dinner base on the recommendation of my dinner party. We got to the restaurant at about 9pm and the front of the restaurant was empty. We were worried the place is closed.

We quickly noticed the door is unlocked and went inside. The wait staff told us to seat ourselves, which we did.  The back room feels warm, and I really enjoy the atmosphere.

As the weather is rather chilly, we had a pot of green tea to warm ourselves. We ordered 3 savory crepes  for dinner: Milano, Tuscany and Santa Fe. Each crepe came with a side of sauteed potatoes and tossed green salad. The salad is very simple, with almost too little dressing. There are some bitter greens which highlighted the salad very well. 

The potatoes are uneven. Some pieces are crispy, which I prefer, but some are mushy. They are perfumed with rosemary, which I enjoyed very much. 

Finally, I really enjoy my Tuscany crepe. The filling of chicken, mushroom and pesto worked really well. The only complain is the dressing is a little too oily. 

The crepe themselves are very thin, but have dried up a little during the cooking process. Still quite good for my taste.

Service was efficient, though not very friendly. I personally enjoyed being left alone as we were enjoying our conversations.

The total bill came to $35 before tips. A solid restaurant, just a tad too expensive for the quality of food.
author: hsiao c.

description:
The menu does not change much - if at all - but it's all great. I love the service and my 5-year old daughter loves eating here. They are friendly and the kids meals are a good value even though it's cheaper to get a normal eggs and pancake adult meal rather than 1 Bacon n eggs and 1 Pancake kids meal at other places in town. 

The food tastes like a variation of Squat and Gobble and crepe places in the city but better. Outside seating in back is great on nice days but limited seats in and outside which fills up quickly.
author: James T.

description: Went for brunch with the fam on Sunday at about noon.  Loved the call ahead wait list and only had to wait about 10 min for a table since we called.  They were very sweet and accomodating with 2 young kids.  I knocked over my bellini and they were so sweet about replacing it.  Made substitutions without a problem (although they did charge for changing the type of salad) with both our meals and the kids meals.  Food came out quick and everybody was helpful.  Wish we lived closer!
author: Manisha S.

description: worst restaurant experience in quite awhile.
author: Kenya l.

description:
I had high expectations since there always seems to be a queue outside. The interior design is nice, but...
they are terribly understaffed and,
the taste was average or below.
author: Peter O.

description:
It's crazy how varied people's experiences are at Savor.  I went for brunch on a Saturday morning, at about 10 am.  Our wait was only about 20 minutes, which isn't horrible - although I think we just beat the rush.  We had a small table in the back, smooshed into the corner, so much so that someone at the table next to us had to get up so that we could be seated.  Service was a bit slow, but the waitress was nice and obviously being overworked.  

We each got different egg dishes - I'm a sucker for scrambled eggs with smoked salmon, and their version definitely met my expectations.  Coffee was hot and bitter, just the way I love it.  And the decor of the restaurant was warm and welcoming, but still a bit hip.  

But to be honest, I don't know if I'd go back.  Maybe for dinner, but I just don't like knowing that I'll have to wait for breakfast foods.
author: Tina H.

description:
This has been one of my standby restaurants since I moved to SF.  I've noticed some of the same servers there for 4 years, which is always a good sign.  I've always been happy with my food. Happy would actually be an understatement when it comes to the cornbread with jalapeno jelly. Hello! Delicious.

There is no shortage of crepe joints in SF, and I think Savor does crepes quite well.  I should also mention that their pancakes, salads, and potatoes are delicious.  

They lose a star for reports of so-so meals by some friends and family.
author: Abby W.

description:
Savor is great for brunch or for midweek dinners - located on 24th Street in the heart of Noe Valley, Savor is a casual, friendly neighborhood restaurant with a great menu of healthy choices. 

We like to go to Savor midweek for their generously sized salad portions - select from a wide variety of salads with delicious cheeses and veggies, then choose if you want to add grilled tofu, chicken or salmon on top. Every time I've had salmon here on my salad, it's fresh and delish. I highly recommend the Granada salad with salmon. 

Or, if you're in the mood for brunch foods at any time of day, stop by Savor for some savory crepes, eggs, omelets, pancakes, and more. Anytime we have friends visiting from out of town, we head here for breakfast, the generous brunch portions are enough to keep you full all day long! 

In addition to indoor seating, they have a great outdoor patio with outdoor seating as well - if you come on a Saturday or Sunday morning, expect a wait though it usually goes by pretty quickly.
author: Heather F.

description:
Very generous portions... Crepes, omelettes and Benedicts are all very tasty. 

There's almost always a wait on the weekends, but I don't mind because Ambiance is right down the street.

If you're in the area it's worth checking out...
author: Nenette Y.

description:
For a great brunch venue to catch up with friends you haven't seen in a while, while sipping divine mimosas & enjoying great conversation and food -- Savor is my #1 choice - hands down!

The outdoor patio on a nice day is an absolute-must, and totally worth waiting for (they have heat lamps too), and the ambiance inside is super condusive to a sane conversation (where you aren't shouting just to hear the other person).

Some other imperatives:
- Corn bread w/ jalapeno jelly -- you'd be insane to skip out on this devilishly tasty appetizer.
- The "Petra" sandwich -- yelps of happiness in every bite; yes, it is possible...

Lost star? - The wait drives you insane, but ultimately worth it, as is often the case...
author: Anjali V.

description:
If I were to rate this strictly on mimosas, I would give it 5 stars.  I love the mimosas here...they are huge and they do not skimp on the champagne!!

The food, however, isn't that great.  I mean it's not bad...just average.  The portions are HUGE though.  You can easily order one entree and split it.  So you definitely are getting your money's worth.  I have been here twice for brunch and both times I felt some of the dishes are lacking in flavor.  I do like the outdoor seating area....it's really nice to sit out there on a warm day...and even if it's not so warm, some of the seats have a heater above them.

I would go back if I was craving a really good mimosa :)  And it helps that the place is really close to where I stay in SF.
author: Neety P.

description:
Definitely another one of my neighborhood favorites!! I love coming here for breakfast as everything I've ordered has been amazing. I came here for dinner once also, which was very good, but their breakfast is by far the best thing on the menu. The prices are very reasonable and you get a ton of food. I always have left overs, and if I don't it's because it was so good I couldn't stop eating!!

The pancakes (all of them) are my favorite on the menu, french toast is also very very good. I usually order pancakes half of one kind and half of another. Great way to get all of my favorites in at once! The scrambles are tasty but the omelets have too much egg and are generally too big for my liking (but I'm not a huge fan of eggs). I wish they had a tofu scramble.

The patio is great for sunny days in the Noe. Although there is almost always a wait, it's totally worth it! The service is fast and the staff is friendly. For something different, try the corn bread with jalapeno jelly.
author: Ashleigh S.

description:
There are a lot of methods of evaluating a restaurant. Solely the food? The service, ambiance, or value? I always hate to trash talk a place because just one of those things was subpar. However, occasionally, they just f you over and that's never cool!

I went for brunch with a few friends.  The garbage disposal and I were starving and still growing accustomed to dining out sans gluten (it's scarier than Walmart on Black Friday!).  We ordered the Santa Fe omelet and the Arizona with no toast.  The waiter assured us that they get gluten free people in there all the time (heck, it's Noe, aka stroller valley) and that both dished we ordered were safe.  The boyfriend's dish arrived with toast on it and we prompted asked if we could have a new one.  A few minutes later, they came back with what we thought was a fresh plate.  We enjoyed our meal- not too bad, but not as good as Chloe's down the street.  The 3-egg omelets were cooked well and they weren't stingy with the fillings.  I then realized that I had a square of butter on my plate but couldn't think of why they put it there (for my hash browns maybe?).  We paid for our $12 omelets and headed home.  Then all hell broke lose, gluten city.

I find it unacceptable that a restaurant would lie about accommodating for food allergies... in Noe Valley no less!
author: Cersei T.

description: Despite the overly decorated cocktails, the food was good & reasonably priced. Service was quick, tho our server clearly didn't give a rat's a$$ about his job... I had a savory crepe (the san fran) and K had one of the "benedictions". And good cocktails (bloody mary's spicy!).
author: eric k.

description:
Delicious, but not compelling: my omelet was an omlete, eggs blackstone, delicious, but blackstone.  The french toast had egg only on the outside, not soaked all the way through. I don't care either way, but its a differentiating factor, so I mention it.

Would I go back? Yes, because the wait is not too long to get in during peak brunch hours, and Noe Valley is a great neighborhood to walk around in while you wait.
author: Mehul P.

description:
One of my favorite brunch places (maybe cause I can walk...or stumble depending upon the night before).  Seating is usually fast unless you try to come during the weekend brunch rush.  There is usually a good sized line and a 30-40 minute wait.  It is worth the trouble though.

The dining area is rather large and wraps all the way from the front, down the hall and into the back which include a very nice open air patio.  This is one of the nicer patios in the city.

Typically service is quick although you will get the occasional hiccup.  Their menu is a brunchers paradise.  Scrambles, pancakes, french toast, crepes (savory and sweet), eggs benedict, salads and sandwiches.  Kinda hard to go wrong with all the choices...which might be one of the only problems.  Too many choices.  It can be hard to pick sometimes but I have sampled most of the items on the menu and you will likely not go wrong.  

My favorites include all of the Eggs Benedicts as they do an excellent job.  Probably my favorite in the city.  The scrambles and the crepes are well worth the effort.  The sandwiches are done well but in my opinion stick to the brunch side of the menu.

All-in-all an excellent choice.  If you can, get here during the week day so you can enjoy with less wait and a little more peace and quiet on the back patio.
author: Dean H.

description:
Another inspiration find in the quest for the ultimate SF brunch. This journey took me to 24th street in the heart of Noe Valley. The wait for this little gem was a little excessive, but deserving upon scarfing down some of it's dilectible brunch treats. With a latin flare, Savor creates a different brunch take with a little more flavor and bite. Highly recommended. 


The Low Down:
Atmosphere: Spanish/Latin 
Price: $$ (15)
Selling Point:
author: Kaleb L.

description:
We went here after finally getting the clue that Miss Millie's had closed. It was pretty good, especially considering our disappointment about MM's. It definitely reminded me of Crepevine, nothing really new, but good menu nonetheless. My omelete with the soy chorizo was good, a little heavy on the black bean though, but still really tasty. The only thing I wish they could have done is let me substitute a little piece of their cornbread for the toast included with the egg dishes - I did want to try this famous stuff but didn't want to pay $4.50 for more cornbread than I could eat.

Even though it was a Saturday morning and there was a line, it went pretty quickly, and people seemed to be getting their food right away. They let you help yourself to free coffee while you wait. My friends had the oatmeal pancakes and the chicken apple scramble. Also good. Our waitress was a little bit MIA but the rest of the staff made up for it, even two different waiters alerting me to the second bathroom when they saw me waiting outside of the first one.
author: Spratt M.

description:
I love this place! 

One, breakfast food served all day? Could anyone ask for more?

I've only been here three times, but all the things I ordered were delicious. You can sit out on the patio out back and get some sun. Good place to go and just sit and enjoy your food on the weekend. The mainly serve breakfast food, but they do have sandwiches, some soup and salad. Most of their dishes come with a mixed green salad and home potatoes for a very satisfying meal. Mmmm...makes me hungry just to think about it! 

If you like spicy, the Baja scramble is delicious. 

The Tuscany and Singapore Crepes are good as well.

Can't wait to try all their other food!
author: Nicole K.

description:
So sue me, I didn't do the crepe thing at Savor.  I ordered a burger.  It was a really good burger with all the fixins and I'd order it again.

BTW, Savor reminds me of a higher end Crepevine, with actual service,  better seating (outdoor), beers, and a certain San Francisco flair.
author: Pelle Y.

description:
I thought the food was good when you get it.  Either our server had a long night the night before or he's just totally out of it.  It took him about 10 mins to take our coffee order, 15 mins to take our food order, it took about 25 minutes to get our order and our order was wrong.  We asked for no capers and we got capers, we ordered the jalapeno bread and they "forgot to make it."  After that, we got some attention from our server.  He asked us if we wanted more coffee about 3 times, unfortunately our cups were never filled and then he mysteriously disappeared to the point where his collegues didnt even know where he went.  

Alright, so enough abou the weird service at Savor and on to the food.  I had the Tuscany Crepe which was really yummy.  It had pesto, almonds, chicken, and sun dried tomatoes.  It also came with a side of veggies and rosemary potatoes.  Prices are decent and the portions are more than genorous.  The line looks intimidating but the wait is actually not too bad.  We only waited for about 10 minutes on a Saturday morning.
author: Jen L.

description:
Met an ex-colleague for lunch here today.  The staff was extremely friendly and helpful.  While waiting for my friend, I inquired about the soup of the day which was creamy tomato basil and was offered a tasting.  It turned out to be very nice and I had it for my lunch.

I had the soup / salad lunch combo.  When it arrived, I was surprised at the size of the soup - a very large bowl!  The salad was a healthy portion as well.

The server was sooo attentive and friendly - extremely rare during a lunch time meal.

Will definitely come here again.
author: Yuan W.

description:
The food is decent/mediocre for the price and the outdoor patio is nice enough. I guess I just like to be treated a bit better when I dine out.

The service is pretty awful in general, I'm sure there are exceptions if you get the right server, I had mixed experiences, my first time here was decent, the second time, really, really bad. This is important to me so it has the biggest impact on my rating. 

I think the food is certainly overpriced, there are better brunch options in SF so not my first choice. Example of overpriced, my friend didn't want the toast or homefries with her omelette, she asked for a side of fruit instead (so they were breaking even if anything), our waiter said it would cost extra, it turned out to be $3.50 extra and I kid you not contained 5 small slices of fruit in a tiny ramekin. My iced soy chai was watered down and gross (& overpriced of course).

It took us 15 minutes to flag down our server for the check when we were ready to go. He completely ignored us the whole time (didn't bring us the food someone else ran it out, never asked how it was, never refilled our water or asked if we wanted anything else). The ONLY time he came by was about 5 minutes prior to us finishing up. He went to grab my plate before we had finished our food. I asked him politely to please not to take them just yet, we needed a minute, so then I think he decided to give us PLENTY of time (even though others were waiting for an outdoor patio table on the beautiful sunny Sunday last weekend) then took 20 more minutes to not come back to take our table to provide change or if it was a card to run it through we had to take it up to the host station to take care of, which is not normally how things run there from what I understood from the apologetic host.

That was the final straw for making this barely a 1 star review. Not going back since I don't feel they really wanted our business, I can take it elsewhere thanks.
author: Abby W.

description:
There is no better way to cap off a great weekend than with a wonderful Sunday brunch at your favorite breakfast bistro.  

And, Savor in Noe Valley is my place.

My fiancé and I love brunch and quickly fell head over heels in love with Savor.  It is quaint, the service is impeccable, the wait time is minimal (and even if not, love spending the time shopping in all the boutiques on the street!) the milieu is warm and the food .. well, is perfect.  The omelets are cooked to perfection and they use Aidells sausage, along with other local brands.  I love their mimosas and the pumpkin pancakes .. we try to cap off every wonderful weekend with a brunch at Savor!

Trust me, after one cozy Sunday brunch, you will fall in love too!
author: Bridget W.

description: Love their portions, a definite breakfast place. I always leave with a full stomach and the reasonable pricing always has me coming back.
author: Jennifer V.

description:
I love Savor, its like an old sweater you just want to cosy down with. This place is a gem - Its value for money and the food rocks .

My fave is the Baja scramble - try it!!!!
author: Stuart g.

description:
Went here for brunch on a weekend. It was very packed and we sat in the back, outside. Great location.

Great breakfast potatoes on the side, which was actually better than the crepe itself.
author: G J J.

description: I have actually been to Savor a few times. The food is okay. This time I had the Americano. They cook it just right. Nothing to go 'wow' about. I left full but meh..it wasn't something I would rave about it. I tried their pancakes, not a huge fan of thick pancakes.
author: SF S.

description: I will rate Savor now after 6 years of consistently good food coming to my table with friends and family as guests. I do not know why other cafes are rated higher. Savor has ambience, and excellent food. The wait staff could be happier and more friendly and helpful in general but they are fine and average. The portions and price match, the eggs are properly done and the flavors are fresh at all times. It is also great to be able to have salad on a plate with eggs.
author: Jill A.

description: Savor gets three stars because I'm relatively indifferent about this place.  I don't hate it or resist when my friends insist we do brunch here.  But I certainly don't crave it.   The food is good, but there's just something missing, ya know?  And I've been here several times, so it wasn't just a fluke bad morning. I've just never loved it.  The service is good, although there is often an excessive wait to get a table on a weekend morning, unless you're there on the early side.  They do have a large outdoor patio for those beautiful San Francisco days, which is a definite plus.  Overall, I could take it or leave it.
author: Natalie N.

description: Every time I go to Savor I like it less. The first times I went here, I liked it, then it got mediocre, then just ok, flip to a couple months ago, I went and had the raisin French toast, they were only ok and I wish I hadn't ordered them. Then couple months later, I came here and had the oatmeal pancakes. Gross! They tasted like cardboard and were just a cakey gluey mass like what you get from the cafeteria as a kid. But thicker. I did not want to go again, but the other day my friends really wanted to go and I got tired of being the bitchy naysayer so I finally relented and let us come here. My friend got the buttermilk pancakes, with strawberries and chocolate chips, and it tasted like..see my description above. They were so bad that he wanted to exchange them. But the waitress, who jumped on us literally the second we were seated, abandoned us the whole meal after our food came. My other friend and I were done with our meals before she even came over, asking if we're done, when he was able to tell her what happened and ask for something different. I didn't ask for something different, but mine was also bad. I got the crabcake egg special. It's a poached egg on top of a crab cake on top of an English muffin, with sauce over it all. I always love, or at least like, crab things. This crabcake was bleh. Was I eating catfood? The fruit that came with it was pretty good. The homefries were boring and I had just two bites. The English muffin was kinda soggy but really, that crabcake. I ate one and a half of the two and my stomach hurt the entire day, night and into the next day. Was the meal all bad? No. the corn bread is pretty tasty, we all enjoyed it. The sangria was good too. It comes by the glass and is actually more of a sake drink rather than a real sangria, pretty strong, but tasty. The other friend liked his hash dish well enough and the savory crepe that replaced the bad pancakes wasn't anything special but it wasn't bad. The good thing is, after this time, these friends said I don't have to come back. Yippee! Oh, and they have a pretty nice back patio, so you can come here for just drinks and cornbread with jalapeño sauce and enjoy the weather.
author: Merredith L.

description: Very good place for large portions.  I had a salad and it was beyond huge. There is a large variety of choices and the staff is really friendly.  It is also located on a great street with plenty of novelty shops.  Love Noe Valley!!  It is a bit like Squat & Gobble, but better!
author: Stephanie F.

description:
Savor is a popular place for Breakfast,Lunch and Dinner.  You can expect to wait 30 minutes for a table on weekend mornings.    They have a great menu with Crepes, Salads, Fish, Chicken and Chops.  Creative recipies and a nice wine list.  Dont forget to order the Corn Bread with Jalapeno Jelly  

Thumbs UP:  Nice staff and casual  environment.  Well executed, quality meals at a good price 
Thumbs DOWN:  Expect to wait for a table during peak meal times, especially breakfast on the weekend.
author: Jeff C.

description:
A cute place in Noe Valley. I love to go their for their breakfast food, especially on those mornings where you had been drinking the night before and your stomach is rumbling with anger-hunger. And it really is a great place because their omelets are GIGANTOSAUR and Pretty gosh darn affordable. 

If you're into Huevos rancheros - i recommend the coronado omelet!
author: Sheena U.

description:
Delicious food at truly (not just SF) affordable prices.
I don't think anything on the dinner menu tops more than $20!

Service has been good the three times I went, none of which were when the place was packed.  The outdoor back patio is lovely as well.

The two points for improvement would be the wine list - Woodbridge on a wine list?  Most places wouldn't admit to using that as cooking wine!  Yuck.  The other few wines available didn't impress either.

Second, this is one of the many crepes restaurants that uses the same batter for both savory and sweet crepes, which I don't understand at all.  I would expect SF restaurants to be at least as good as those in Michigan, but on the crepes they miss the target by never having the buckwheat batter for savory crepes!  

Otherwise, a nice place to eat - I will go back for the entrees and value.

*Update* August 21 - Savor has the best Fettucine Alfredo I've had in the Bay Area.  The sauce doesn't separate and there was freshly softened cloves of garlic.  Super!
author: laura g.

description:
I hate reviewing a place after only eating there once, but not enough to not review it after only eating there once. 

So, last Friday after spending at least 45 min trying to find parking first in the Lower Haight and then in the Castro, we ended up in Noe Valley, ahhhh parking, right on 24th St., and settled down at Savor (obviously, right) for dinner.  I'd have to say I had one of the most mediocre steaks.  Not cooked medium rare as God intended it to be cooked, a bit dry, and just not very flavorful.   The garlic potatoes on the side were nice, and good fresh veggies.  And our baked brie started was nice, i wish there was a bit more jalepeno jelly for it.

The waitress was pretty good, made sure we were happy and our waters were full.  And the bench with pillows that i didn't get to sit on (but am not bitter about) looked comfy.

Some of the crepes sounded good, and probably are, but what's the story with all the creperies in SF?  If I lived way up in NV, I'd go have a nice patio crepe brunch sometime.
author: Adrian L.

description:
A little advice for those for those of you new to eating out.  For a first visit always order whatever the restaurant specializes in.  

At Savor that means get a savory crepe.  The Milano is especially good, but many others are also excellent.   

If you are looking for something a bit different, try this place.  If you are looking for a froofy brunch or a rootie tootie fresh and frootie breakfast, then try elsewhere.
author: Dan W.

description:
For the past couple of years I've been hearing such RAVE reviews about this place. I finally had the chance to try it...and was not very impressed.

We came on a Saturday at around 930-10am before the big breakfast rush hit. We were seated...and it took 15 minutes for anyone to even give us a glass of water. They had a few things that looked tasty on the menu..but a regular breakfast meal of eggs, AMERICAN BACON (on the menu they only talk about "canadian" bacon...it's not real bacon..it's just sliced ham) that I had to ask for, potatoes, and toast for $10!! CRAZY! Their portion are big though but still...you can get that at Denny's for $5.99. 

It's a good place...overpriced. I prefer Crepevine!
author: Jazmine S.

description:
On our two visits here, the roast beef special and the salmon crepe were great... definitely above average entrees.  The $5 mimonsa has me feeling great and it was well worth the price.  

Service was fine on our visits so no complaints there.

It's a top choice for me in Noe Valley.  We'll be back again soon.
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
Extra yummi food, and big portions too. I really wish I could have had a sweet crepe, but the savory one killed me. Food = A+...but thats a lot of places in SF.

I went for brunch on a weekend, yes, I had to wait (duh...I'm blown away people complained). But it was only about 30 minutes. In all reality, not too bad.

Friendly servers, cool crows, and chill decor. It fits the feel of the place nicely. For brunch, meals seemed to be reasonably priced (expect ~$10 for a main plate). Can't wait to go back!
author: Sean C.

description:
One of my absolute favorite spots.  Love the salads - the Granada being my favorite, with the Thai salad a very close runner up, and I always order them with grilled chicken on top.  These salads are so delicious that I hardly ever order anything else, but when I have, I've never been disappointed.  The crepes are wonderful -- my fav being the strawberry, banana and nutella crepe, served with a scoop of vanilla bean ice cream with a matching sized scoop of freshly made whipped cream.  Oh soooooo gooooood!!!!

The only downside for me is that it is always so loud inside that I have a hard time having a conversation.  Must be the accoustics mixed with the location of the kitchen, plus the fact that it's always busy.  On the bright side, there is a lovely patio outside that is much quieter and if it's chilly -- no problem, there are heaters.
author: Theresa J.

description:
This place was awesome! So much better than I expected! 

Since I was to tag along with my dad on a business trip to SF, I did some research ahead of time, and looked for some restaurants that might be interesting. This popped up, because I was interested in a place that served crepes. And many people seemed to review it and liked it, so it went on my list.

We got there, and it's definetely somewhat hidden, kind of like this tiny place that you would never really notice was there, and it doesn't look like much from the outside. But then you walk in, and there's and outdoor patio with tables and then the restaurant part which looked nice too. Since it was beautiful outside that day, we sat out on the patio. Our waiter was very nice and attentive, which I was impressed by because it was really busy that day. The menu was great, and the prices were great too. I had a salad with seared tuna slices, hard boiled egg, fingerling potatoes, green beans and a whole bunch of other stuff that I don't remember. It was HUGE (I was happy), and I didn't finish it all, my dad had to help me eat it. My dad ordered the salmon crepe, and I only had a few bites of it, but it was amazing. I wish I had some more. 

Surprisingly, out of all the restaurants we visited during our time in San Francisco, this was definetely my favorite. Their portions were really generous, and the prices seemed low for how much food they were giving you. The crepes are definetely the best though. I wish they had more restaurants like this around.
author: Rachel Q.

description: Crowded, noisy, and mediocre food with below average service.  Good luck with parking.  Don't understand why it's always crowded.
author: D C.

description: Eat at this place about 4 times and will go there anytime of the day. Awesome food, unbelievable service. Price is perfect.  Salmon omelet is a must, and last time got Pork chops, were beautifully done and flavors were melting in the mouth. I would recommend this place to all.   Sit by the fire place.
author: Rizwan B.

description:
Yum! I have been going to Savor off and on for a few years now! 

+1 Yummy crepes and flexible about changing the menu. I had the barcelona minus the mushrooms and plus chicken and we shared the Sienna dessert crepe (nutella, strawberries, and nuts).
+1 Ambiance - easy to hear your conversation, have a fire going on at night, comfy pillows against the wall.
+1 Service! In the past it was sort of on and off but our server last night was very sweet and attentive. 
+1 Parking - In spite of people complaining that there is no parking in Noe valley, I always find a spot within 5 minutes every time - most likely because it is not one of the trendier areas to hang out in by comparison, and I hope it stays that way! 

Aside from chains like Squat and Gobble or Crepes a gogo I haven't had much to compare to crepe-wise in SF. This is a cozy little eatery that is perfect for a foggy evening, especially if you are seated near the fire! They also have a big patio for one of those rare warm sunny days! I recommend. They also used to have bottomless mimosas for brunch, but not sure if that is going on anymore or not.
author: Kristi D.

description: I came here today for a light quick meal before shopping. Got the Tuscan Crepe, side of Caesar salad and a mango ice tea. I shared my meal with my friend and we were full and satisfied. I like the pine nuts in my crepe, only one complaint, too much pesto! If it was lighter on the pesto would of been perfect. Ice tea was good, staff was nice.
author: Karen T.

description: I came with a group and found out quickly that we should have split meals.  The portions were huge!  Great food, plan on a dog bag if ordering individually.
author: Kelly M.

description: Im not really a fan of breakfast but SAVOR changed me :)  the breakfast here is huge and its inexpensive.  for $11 i got the EL PASO which consist of potatos, 2 eggs, hash, toast, and a cup of fruit.  It was so delicious I ate 95% of what was on my plate.  The customer service here is beyond great.  The waitress came by over 5 times to check on us.  I will definitely come back... if only Im not watching what I eat :)
author: Mimi S.

description:
I'm not crazy about brunch, but if I were, Savor would be near the top of my brunch list. Bill Burr said it best; brunch is the biggest scam...you pay $20 for eggs and toast. The highlight of my visits here are the cornbread and jalapeno jelly. There's a good selection of omlettes and crepes here in addition to the standard brunch sandwiches. Try the san francisco crepe with salmon (i switch mine to the smoked variety), spinach and havarti. It's really tasty and i convince myself that the spinach makes up for the cheese.

Other good choices are the coronado omlette with bold soutwestern flavours that can make you forget you're eating eggs and the cote d'azur with delicate silky hollandaise sauce.

I would give this place another half star if they had fresh squeezed orange juice. What kind of self respecting brunch spot tries to compete in the big leagues without your basic fresh squeezed OJ? The Odwalla is hardly a worthy substitute but it beats the concentrate. I'd go here, when i have to go to brunch, and i'd go here for the cornbread.
author: Alexander S.

description: We found Savor while in S.F looking for a dog friendly restaurant. Wow, I really can't say enough.....  The best part is they serve breakfast all day! ( until I think 10pm!!) One of those places where it took a while to order because there were 10 things on the menu I wanted. Not super fancy, sandwiches, crepes sp?, breakfast, veggie burgers, salads, beers....Awesome. We did have our dogs with us..they have a sneaky alley which leads to an enclosed patio with heaters!!( it was windy and cold so this was just what we needed. As posted here on yelp ( how we found savor:) The French toast is T.d.F.  Everything seemed to come with potatoes & fruit or fries and a salad, huge portions. Now, the only reason I'm giving it 4 stars instead of 5 is the French fries were not good and the side salad was bland. Although I had so much other really good food I was still full. Our server was really nice, he was perfect...hubby had to joke about the t.d.f. French toast posting and the server rolled with it. They brought out water for our dogs. We loved it!
author: Blake O.

description:
Well, this is my opinion, not facts. I like traditional breakfast fare, and although Savor has some of it, the environment and some of the dishes are very non-traditional.

If you would like a mix of traditional and non-traditional (and you like crepes), this is the place to go. They make their food well!
author: Catherine L.

description:
First review: Great place for weekend brunches --- simple, hearty and spicy fare, and the cornbread with jalapeno jelly is to die for. It's a little overpriced but the quiet of the backdoor patio is worth it, especially when the weather's nice. My favorites are the crepes --- the smoked salmon and the apple sausage are done quite well. Service is friendly and reasonably prompt.

Added 12/05: I recently discovered that dinner is great too; tried the ceviche and a chicken dish that were really good. We turned up close to 10p, but they were gracious enough to let us in and feed us. Warmed my heart --- my rating goes up!
author: Sameer S.

description:
One of my first 5-star finds in San Francisco.  I ended up going here for brunch with a group of friends.  Although the wait can be long, the food is worth the wait.  Huge portions and fresh ingredients.  I ordered the corned beef hash and it was real corned beef with diced red potatoes.  Yummy!  On the occasional time I have gone to Savor for dinner, I've ended up ordering the peanut butter and chocolate crepe (I want to say it was the Kilauea, but I'm not sure) with multiple spoons for everyone to share .  This dessert comes second only to the ginger cake/caramel sauce/pumpkin ice cream at Chow.

EDIT: I am told by someone who used to work here, the reason it is so good is because one of the original chef's here was a transfer from Dottie's True Blue Cafe.  I am tending to believe her because the Cornbread with Jalepeno Jelly is damn near identical to Dottie's.  Coincidence?
author: Don O.

description:
As far as breakfast goes in this city, Savor fairs high in my book. The food is excellent and the service is great. When you order their corned beef, its real corned beef, not some crap from a can. Swedish and Pumpkin pancakes are insanely good too.

Crowds can be insane, but if you go early enough, thats not an issue.

Bully.
author: Lord Mandrake P.

description:
Savor used to be one of my favorites. I've been there several times in the last year or so, and it's just not that good anymore. If you're allergic to eggs there's very little to eat, plus the wait staff are annoyed at questions. The long wait isn't worth it really.  
 The orange juice is fresh and good. Honestly crepevine is just as good and the employees are indifferent instead of pissy, and it's cheaper.
author: vickie j.

description:
This is my favorite brunch place when eating with friends. I usually get the Costa Del Sol (poached eggs with spinach on english muffins with hollandaise sauce) or the Petra sandwich (grilled minced chicken kababs on a bread roll with onions). The chicken kabab salad (forget the name) is pretty good too.

The staff rock, they are super friendly and very accomodating. The wait isnt that bad on weekends (30 mins or so at the most) and parking isnt very hard to find.
author: viv k.

description:
If the Queen of Jordan ate here, it must good...right? Well, I suppose. I wish our neighborhood could have entertained a royal at higher-quality (in terms of food) establishment. Their fruit crepes are delish...the savory ones not so much. I have been going to Savor since I was in elementary school (over a decade ago), and as far as desserts go, they've always been right on the mark. The place is always packed - particularly on weekends for brunch.

I went with my brother on a late Sunday afternoon recently, and tried my hand at a Mazatlan crepe. First, the fork was obviously dirty and I noticed this even before I sat down in the patio area in the back. I asked the waitress for a new one, but she forgot, and by the time my food came, I had to go to inside the restaurant and find one off an empty set table. I also asked for the crepe to not include sour cream...which of course it did. The salad and the potatoes on the side weren't bad, but the crepe itself nearly made me sick. I was sort of shocked, and I have made a vow to only order sweet crepes to savor on.
author: Rachel K.

description:
savor, i'm just not that into you. Sorry. 24th street has a surprisingly poor bfast/lunch scene and perhaps the crowds here are more due to the dearth of good choices than its own quality. 

Why am i so down? Well, there's just nothing that special. The food is ho ho hum. I've never had a problem with service and eating outside sure is nice, so no harm no foul, if you like this place that's cool, just not for me.
author: hunter w.

description:
When I first moved to my new neighborhood (Noe Valley. Yeah. I live in the neighborhood of strollers, families, and dogs), I was stoked to find that I was walking distance from several eateries and didn't have to dive into my car anymore for a bite to eat.

On my first morning in my new digs, I did a search for breakfast places in Noe Valley. I came across this place. SWEET! Yet another crepe place. They can either be really, really good, or.. mediocre. I decided to give it a shot.

My first time at Savor was satisfactory. I was seated quickly, even though they were busy. The only thing I really had to complain about was their  "spicy bloody mary". It was.. can I say it? TOO SPICY. I fully expect my Bloody Marys to have a kick, but this thing was pure spice and no flavor. I left half of it on the table, and abusing alcohol in that sense is typically OUT OF THE QUESTION for me.

My second time there, I took my parents, who were in town for the day. They seated us right away, but after serving us our drinks, they decided to move us to a different table because a couple of lonely housewives were complaining behind us about their own table "not being in the right location". I found it offensive that, instead of telling them to wait for a new table to open up, they decided to just move us poor little innocents to appease these women. We were pretty nonplussed, but trudged on and ordered anyway. Both of my parents' crepes were good, but my scramble left something to be desired. The eggs were overdone, the ingredients poorly paired. It was bland, even with copious amounts of salt and pepper added. I ended up leaving half of that on my plate.

My third time there, I was seated quickly again. After 20 minutes of waiting for so little as a nod of acknowledgment from the waitstaff (to no avail), I walked out. The place was empty. There was no reason for the lack of attention.

So, Savor, you had my hopes up for a while, but seeing as how your service has gotten increasingly worse every time I've been there.. I give up the ghost.  You've made me commit three of my biggest taboos -- alcohol abuse, food abuse, and walking out of a restaurant.

No more!
author: Kym L.

description: Savor is our go to neighborhood place. Fresh ingredients, affordable, great staff. Please bring back the tuna tartar!!!
author: memi s.

description: Ok brunch spot, but not worth all the rave reviews. If you are in Noe and the wait is reasonable, go to Savor. If you aren't in Noe or the wait is over 10 minutes, skip it because you'll be disappointed.
author: Stinky M.

description:
Nice brunch place... If you go on weekends, go early. The portions are big, the offerings are tasty and the staff is friendly. The ambiance is always cozy and warm too. 

My favorite is their New Orleans: A Crab Cake Egg Benedict... YUMMM!
author: Oz O.

description:
Hubby's Review:

Great food for brunch.  Good service.  Long waits on weekends.
author: Mr. and Mrs. L.

description:
Good brunch spot.  Nice atmosphere.  Great location.

The Provence Scramble was very good.  (Fresh salmon, spinach, onions, goat cheese).

A great brunch spot in my opinion will have fresh squeezed orange juice (they had odwalla).  Nit picking, I know, but 4 stars have to be worked for in my opinion.

I'd definitely go back.  And I'll update my review when I do.
author: Liz B.

description:
Had brunch there with a couple of friends.  So many choices on the menu and they all looked good.  The portions were big so I was not able to finish my  meal.  But definitely a nice place to go to a warm, lazy Sunday afternoon.

You usually have to wait to get a table but on a nice day time passed by rather quickly.
author: Rene M.

description:
I would give this place 5 stars for it's outdoor seating area! When's it's a beautiful day, sitting out there makes me feel like I'm not in the city, ...a real way to take advantage of your hour lunch!!!!

But as far as the food, nothing has been awful and nothing that great either! But the crepes are pretty good!!

So perfect experience there for me would be a 74 degree day, sitting in the outside patio area with some girls from work eating our crepes!!
author: M R.

description: Pretty good food, but not great.  I had some sort of spinach crepe with salmon that was good, but oozed oil when pressed.  The person I was with had an Asian style crepe that was pretty boring.
author: Todd R.

description: This place quickly made it to the top of my "go to" breakfast spots in SF. The food is consistently fresh and delicious and the portions are HUGE. That aside the service and atmosphere is also perfect for brunch. Try their jalapeno cornbread!
author: Gina D.

description: After searching on Yelp high and low for a brunch place near Dolores Park, this is what we came up with.  Pretty darn good! Showed up on a Sunday around 11am and was able to walk straight in and get seated.  Menu looked great and our server was very helpful with any changes and substitutions we wanted to make.  The New Orleans crab benedict  so rich and so good.  The barcelona crepe delish.  The french toast with added strawberries great basic french toast.  The burger with mushrooms, onions AND avocado, great.  Portions are huge with a great green salad accompanying and nice home fries.  The latte wasn't too shabby either :) I'll go back for sure.
author: Stacy F.

description:
service = cool
outdoor seating = great
food = what was the chef thinking?

-OK, I am NOT one to bash a chef...but, come ooooon... 
It is called "Risotto Milanese" but there was NO saffron (the main ingredient- i mean at least try and trick us with turmeric) and there were bell peppers in it (NOT an ingredient in Milanese cuisine)
-The Ahi Tartar was fine- I make better
-The steamed spinach was soaked in olive oil, and we specifically asked for "very little"

I think the lack of communication came from the kitchen end- not the servers.

I had a lovely glass of Riesling!

All good, I'd probably give it another shot
author: Claudine D.

description:
Quality of ingredients: AWESOME
Servers: AWESOME
PORTIONS: HUGE!

Hands down, our most favorite breakfast place. They MAKE their food. Noting tastes like it was just taken out of a frozen bag. Their muffins are quite a treat too.
author: Lu V.

description:
Well meaning food, with outstanding combinations of flavors, but it doesn't quite deliver on the goods.  For brunch the egg scramble was watery and palid, and for dinner the special entree of rock cod could have been good but was spoiled by a too-bitter red pepper sauce.  That being said, the service was wonderful.  The server handled the slow service and compliants with a friendly attitude, proactively comped our drinks AND appetizer, and made the meal as pleasurable as it could be.  

And the dessert crepes are still to DIE for.  My advice is to stick to the main crepe-based menu.
author: Cat S.

description:
Based on the glowing reviews, tried place for dinner last Friday--and despite the fact that both of us were STARVING and hadn't eaten lunch, we didn't even come close to finishing our plates because it was just kinda gross.  (we both got crepes).  The food was kinda greasy and didn't really taste like anything.  I very rarely EVER think that about food, especially if I'm that hungry.  On the plus side, the portions were generous and the place was enjoyable to sit in.....but I'll never go there again.  

C'mmon Yelpers--get a little pickier!
author: Adrienne G.

description:
OK, so I've got kids, little ones, and Savor used to be our every weekend brunch spot with them. That's when David was manager. I think I would have given it the five stars back then. David was awesome, always remembered our kids and gave them balloons, sometimes snuck us in early if the line was too long and the kids were getting cranky, and the food was great (not gourmet, but hey, that's not what I'm looking for with kids at 11am). But then David decided to chill out and just work the waiter shift on weekdays and now it seems things have gone downhill a little. The service is slower, and even the food seems a little ho-hum now. Hmmm, come back David!

pro's
-huge portions
-tasty and reasonable food
-friendly and accomodating staff
-nice back yard for sunny days
-and for those sunny days sans kids (or with if they're driving you crazy), one of the most delicious bucks fizzes around!
-free coffee while you wait for a table

cons
-the wait - even with the free coffee it's just too long
-the evening dinner menu is pretty mediocre for the price
-last visit the food was just not quite as nice. Couldn't put my finger on it, and maybe it was a one off thing, but still, expected more
author: emily c.

description:
I love coming to this place for brunch on the weekend.  The wait is worth it- come put your name in and walk down to one of the noe shops or get a cup of coffee while you wait (just don't stay away for too long).  The service is relatively fast and the outside seating area is a nice touch when the weather is sunny.

My default dish here is cote d'azur or costa del sol which come with fabulously flavored potatoes.  The spices are quite good.  I have also tried a couple times from my friend's dishes- french toast parisienne- get  ready for some sweetness in your mouth/ dessert for your meal-  and pancakes-original with fruit which were also good.
author: Maria F.

description:
This is one of my favorite places in the city for breakfast or brunch.
Food is ok, not bad, not great - same as you will find in any usual place. So if you want something exceptional - keep looking. What makes it 4 stars is the place. It's very spacious, with a few fireplaces and quiet atmosphere, very big backyard with sun in the morning (if you into sitting outside). Friendly staff and waiters. Usually on the quiet side and yet not empty.
If you are alone you can be sited within 5-10 minutes even on Sunday morning. Usual wait time for groups is 15-20 minutes I would say.
author: Nazar P.

description: Took my son for breakfast on a Sat no lines, the waitress was really nice the food was really good a bit pricey but 100 times better than Toast, and Joe's Dinner...
author: jerry p.

description: this place was a fabulous little breakfast spot for my hungover self.  $5 bloody mary's that tasted really good and the food was really good/fresh.  The portions were big and the food is reasonably priced. The server was so nice and she gave us great service.  I would def be coming back and try something else.I had a scramble with feta,spinach,muchrooms and tomato.The eggs were scrambled to perfection not overcooked at all and were fluffy. My sis had a salad with salmon.the salmon was cooked perfectly and wasnt dry at all, cooked to perfection.I will be coming back
author: Alexis R.

description: I arrived at savor with my girlfriend around 12:30pm on a Saturday. We waited for about 20 minutes and were able to get a table outside. The restaurant has a list inside, but the wait isn't that bad and there are plenty of interesting stores nearby to check out. Inside, the restaurant has a very Mediterranean feel with warm earth tones and a great little outdoor area. For the service, it was a busy Saturday so that might affect this a little bit. After ordering the pitcher of mimosas, which wasn't a bad deal at $20 for 64 ounces. The wait time was beyond insane and many people who came in after us received their food well before us. We waited about 50 minutes for an omelet and some chicken and waffles... Sad at best. Our waitress, who didn't check on us at all, let us know that there was a new cook in the kitchen after we flagged her down. Not a very good excuse for the situation. Now for the food! :) the Arizona omelet was quite good and cooked to perfection. The sourdough bread was toasted just right and the potatoes were great, with a strong flavor of garlic. The food was good, the service was mediocre. That's my view of this place. I would give it another try just because of the food, but the service almost turned me away for good.
author: Maxim M.

description: My rating is focused on lunch--it would be 3 stars if I included breakfast--big portions, small on favor--BUT, lunch is a different story (still big portions though). I have had all the chicken sandwiches there and they were all great and flavorful; my favorite lunch selection is the salmon sandwich--the Pacific. YUMMY! The back patio is great especially if you have a stroller and the servers are awesome and accommodating. It is a nice treat.
author: Deborah S.

description:
I love Savor! These people know how to fill my hungry belly in the nicest possible way! It is the place I crave to be when I have a hangover!
Its brunch brunch brunch here and the menu is long, varied and it feels kind of healthy too - there is plenty of good veg, salad and other such healthy like options!
I tend to go for the smoked salmon, poached egg english muffin smothered in hollandaise sauce. You get a good sized side of fried potatoes with this and of course a mimosa is de rigeur to accompany all the delicious food! But there are sandwiches, wraps, huge salads and omlettes to choose from too!
The staff are always friendly and generally efficient and I think you get greta value for money. Dining on the patio is always good too if the weather suits!
author: Imogen d.

description:
When it comes to breakfast options in Noe Valley, there aren't that many good choices.  Savor is the exception.  A good mix of traditional egg dishes along with signature crepe, omelette and tasty Eggs Benedict dishes prevail.   Post-breakfast options include a modest selection of salad and sandwiches.

A very casual atmosphere, along with a friendly wait staff, and you've got the perfect weekend morning meal
author: Karl W.

description:
I like the half stars. 3.5 would be accurate.

The food is consistently good, it is not outstanding. This is my standby place to go out for a salad when I don't want a four course meal or anything remotely resembling a scene.  Service is fine. The no reservation thing is meh,  but they do let you call ahead and put your name on the wait list before you get there which generally solves that problem.  

Lunch and brunch are both fine, the brunch crowd gets a little too unabashedly yuppie-fabulous for my taste (I prefer my yuppies self-hating and guilt ridden) hence I prefer Boogaloos or  Foreign Cinema for all hang-over remedying meals.

 Ultimately, an if-you-are-in-the-neighborhood place . . .or good place to take out of town suburban folk .
author: Jen A.

description:
A local Noe Valley weekend brunch hangout, Savor can be easily spotted by looking at the crowd that waits for a table outside in the sidewalk.
Part of the attraction is the patio outside, which has good trees and offers some shade in a sunny day.
The food is good, not excellent. The service is quick, but you may expect some delays in a crowded day.
author: Alex B.

description: Favorite Brunch place in the city. I had one of their crapes and it was bomb.
author: Ben T.

description: Had brunch at Savor today with my partner. I have to say we were very disappointed. We've eaten here several times before and would have given them four stars in the past.  I don't know what's happened with Savor but I would say our potatoes were on the under cooked side. My Tuscan crepe was loaded with pesto that masked the chicken and tomatoes. My partner actually said, of his sandwich, "How do you screw up a club?"  I hope for Savor this was just a bad day.
author: Chris B.

description: I freakin love this place. If we can't think of anywhere to go for dinner savor is our spot because it's always consistently good!! The food is great, the staff is always nice, the place is clean and the menu is never boring!! I highly recommend savor for dinner!! Brunch is great too.
author: Ja A.

description: Savor is a great hip place with courteous servers and a cozy fireplace. We always have the option to eat indoors or outdoors, but we usually eat indoors. Absolutely every time we go the tuna tartare is a must! And the salads are always very flavorful. I don't recommend the fish, it was too spicy and dry.
author: Raquele C.

description:
WOW!! 3 1/2 star average, huh? I haven't read through any of the reviews, but that really surprised me (seems low.) I have never been disappointed, not even close, at Savor.
