The clam chowder was homemade and delicious.  I had a crepe which came with salad and homefries.  It was good and obvious that attention was paid to the combination of ingredients.
What keeps this place from being a five star banger is the fact that it lacks character and is rather large.  That's just me.
author: pauline e.

description:
I've been here a handful of times for brunch/lunch. It never disappoints. The menu is extensive almost to the point of being overwhelming. There is something for everyone here. Don't worry, you get hearty home fries and salad with just about everything on the menu. And for a tater girl, that is definitely worth an extra star. 

I usually always go for the salads--fresh and flavorful and not too drowned down by dressing. But this afternoon I had the Seal Rock (smoked salmon on a bagel). It was my first sandwich there so I can't speak for the rest of the sammies, but I think the crepes and salads are more their forte. The BF had a chicken kabob sandwich that looked mighty tasty tho. Dad had the chicken shwarma special--I stole a bite and it was better than my dish. Sometimes Dads do know best!

Come to Savor for tasty, familiar food and lots of it. Remember to wear your elastic waist pants.
author: Olive O.

description: when it comes to breakfast, i'm your basic eggs, potatoes, toast and breakfast meat girl (is that even that basic?).  i could be a vegetarian if i could give up sausage, but i can't so i'm not.  anyway, savor is a great brunch!  make sure you sit outside on a lovely day.  the mimosas are a good size and the crepes and omelets are to die for.  they meet all my basic needs...and some even have avocado as well which is just icing on the breakfast cake for me.  there usually is a wait, but it's always been less than anticipated.  it's not a bad thing...just increases the hunger pains so you can eat even more of the scrumptiousness when you get your food.
author: Jessica W.

description: I have been a long time patron to Savor so this review comes with a great disappointment. Saturday 4/30 I went to Savor with my family from out of town as I have done many times before. We were sat quickly or rather told to walk to the back and find a spot. The restaurant was not crazy busy but there was several seats taken inside to the rear so we opted to sit outside where there were only two other tables being used. As we settled in the menu came out quickly but no drink order requested, no water brought. We sat there for 25 mins. and there was not 1 glance 1 acknowledgement from the two waitress that came out a total of 9 times between them to attend to the other two tables. I am blown away by this service or lack there of since I have been a loyal customer for the past 5 years. This 1 bad experience will keep me away from patronizing this establishment. We never got water, we never were waited on and as we walked out there was barely a glance in our direction. I tried to say something on my way out but the two waitress and the host seemed to be very consumed with their own conversation.
author: Careey H.

description: Savor was my go-to restaurant when I lived in Noe Valley.  I loved the relaxed atmosphere and yummy brunch (and the awesome crepes).  Get there before 11am on the weekend to avoid the hungover crowds.
author: P V.

description: Nice little place for brunch. We got there just about 10:30 and had no problem getting seated, but soon the masses appeared. I got the french toast which was good. The lady friend got a scramble (Rio Grande). It was good. Service was attentive. I also got an order of poached eggs. They over did the eggs and i said 'medium'.
author: Erik B.

description: we eaten here twice since moving to noe valley and both times the food has been really good.  i love that it's open late at night and their breakfast/brunch menu is available any time.  not super cheap but good food and HUGE portions.  they also have a nice outdoor garden patio out back.  a small wait for brunch on the weekends but not too bad.
author: Cyn B.

description: We went on a Monday, 11 am. At first it didn't look like many people were there, but it was because they were all seated in the back. The portions were large. Mom had an Omlette with spinach, mushrooms and sausage. I had the corned beef hash which was awesome. Real corn beef, not the mushy stuff from a can. It was nice and tender. Not greasy as some places are. Reasonable prices and helpful staff made for an enjoyable meal.
author: Suzanne S.

description: i came here because someone on yelp said that it was comprable to Dottie's. uhh WRONG! it's comprable to Crepevine, which is my favorite default place to go when i don't have anything else in mind. but i'd much rather go to Crepevine. so i guess the lack of stars really is because i had higher expectations of this place. sorry, that's the way the cookie crumbles. and yelpers, if you're going to say something is comprable, please make sure it's actually fitting.
author: Regina C.

description: I've lived down the street from this restaurant for 4 years now and i've eaten here more times than i care to remember.  I've never gotten anything super yummy here, but it is decent food.  You won't get anything mind shattering here, but you won't get anything horrible either.  Solid burger (i think it's called the Baron).
author: Freedy H.

description: Two words Bangkok Salad.... I can't order anything else on the menu!!! Thankfully, my sister and I split this salad and we order something else to share. Huge portions, delicious food this Noe Valley native loves this restaurant. um umm good. :)
author: Judy J.

description: i confess, i've only eaten at savor a few times.  i order take-out from savor, however, at least once a week.  on weeknights when you just don't feel like cooking or going out, and need something quick, easy, and relatively healthy,  their salads make a great dinner, as do their savory crepes, scrambles, omlettes, and sandwiches.  my favorite salad is the golden gate, although i always have them add red onions for additional flavor.  their barcelona crepe and baja scramble are also quite tasty.  their black bean chile and corn bread with jalapeno jelly is really good as well.  their chicken club sandwich is yummy, too, and quite filling.  as far as take-out goes, they have a good selection, and its quite easy for two people to get a satisfying dinner for under 20 bucks.
author: Erin C.

description: Nothing Special with terrible home fries (if you can even call them that).  I find the menu completely boring- would rather go to Crepe Vine- at least they admit to being a low brow breakfast joint.  Service has been ok but what really burns me up are the potatoes.  I have been to this place more than a few times (as a compromise to friends who insist on it) and every time I go I ask for my taters well done.  Not only do they never come well done, they are consistently undercooked.  Who likes undercooked potatoes?  If I ever have to go back I'll bring my electric skillet and show them how it's done!  Do you dare me?
author: Lael S.

description: this place is uber-good but not sure it's uber-worthy of the uber-long lines.
author: Angie Y.

description: Who doesn't love a place that serves breakfast all day long? The crepe with the chicken sausage was good but it was almost room temperature by the time it was served. Our server was nice and the portions were huge. Definitely not worth driving across the city for, but if you're already in Noe, it hits the spot. I think it would be worth coming back when the weather is nice and you can grab a spot on the back patio.
author: Cher E.

description: me like savor.  especially if you sit outside in the garden patio.  so cute and fun.  huge portions and very tasty.  and mimosas to boot.
author: Caroline S.

description: The salads at Savor have got to be some of the best in the city.  Especially because they are a meal by themselves and you can add grilled tofu.  My only complaint is that they don't have the one with goat cheese and marinated apples anymore but the others are wonderful.  Always keeps me coming back.
author: Holly R.

description: Really huge breakfast portions!    It's Noe Valley & they do attract the stroller set.  It  gets noisy inside when full, but it has a nice patio area in the back that's covered so never too hot, and at night, they have gas heaters.  Go there early on the weekends or there's a wait.
author: J T.

description: This is my very favorite Sunday brunch spot. All egg dishes  and crepes are fantastic but I go there for the Pacific Sandwich, pan seared salmon with arugula and caper aioli, yammm! The wait staff is friendly and accommodating.
author: Christina S.

description: i have been twice, but i wouldn't have chosen to go back the second time except my roommate really wanted to go. it's not bad, but it's not fantastic to me. no vegan options, all eggs, no tofu scramble to be found. the corn bread is good, the potatoes are decent, the owner/manager guy and staff is totally nice and sweet so that gives them a thumbs up but i just am not wowed.
author: ms.kiki g.

description: I was delighted with my first visit to Savor.  So many restaurants in the city lack atmosphere.  I consistently feel like I am dining in an unfinished basement, but Savor has a lovely patio and lots of windows that border it.  I came here for brunch, and it was delicious.  The portions are huge, the food was great, and it was inexpensive!  The downside is the wait on a weekend morning, but it's worth it.
author: t l.

description: my favorite place for brunch in noe valley. The courtyard in the back is very charming. Service is great and food is good!
author: Beena A.

description: Always a long line on weekends. But the food is mediocre. Large menu boring food. Had terrible French toast. Went for dinner. Huge salad with lots of sprouts. This place is just OK. Does have a nice deck. Not worth standing in line for. It seems to be the place where you simply must have Sunday Brunch if you are between 25 and 35 years of age.
author: Bob J.

description: It is always crowded here. I went to this restaurant for many times and tried different dishes. Yet, I must say the quality of the food is mediocre. The price is a little too much for that quality. The seats in the patio are nice. The free coffee while waiting is also nice.
author: Charlie S.

description: i love Savor.. this is my neighborhood breakfast spot.. they have the best crepes and to die for omelets.. the salads are awsome too.. Savor is a great place for a hungover crazy weekend.. it just hits the spot... and the service is great and fast.. but yes there is  wait on buzy weekeds
author: Shauna P.

description: this is the kind of place in the middle u cant say anything bad meanwhile u cant say anything extraordinary , its just the average place , i would say smart management and nice menu more than great food  something makes me wantta go back everyonce in a while thats not necessarly a good thing !!!
author: NAEL K.

description: In a neighborhood of good brunch spots, this is...well...a good brunch spot.  It's not worth a long line, but I find these days their line is less than most places in the city on a Sat/Sun morning.  The Baja (spicy) scramble is tops -- pretty much all I ever order there.  It's served with a fire-roasted pepper, poultry sausage, cheese and a side of their delicious rosemary potatos.  I think the crepes tend to disappoint, at least the savory ones.  Also a solid stop off for a light dinner or lunch, as the salads are large and fresh.  I prefer the Athena salad with chicken if you decide to go that route.
author: Jeff L.

description: lots of food for the money at good prices.  come hungry.  very nice service.
author: e w.

description: The food at savor is consistently tasty.  It's a cute place with a great outdoor seating area in the back.  I hadn't been in a while, and today's experience was just as good, EXCEPT they charged me for a another lemonade when they came by and refilled my glass without asking if I wanted another lemonade.  That is annoying.
author: Claire P.

description: The service was good, potatoes were good, but the rest ... not good.  I had eggs benedict with spinach and avocado:  the benedict was yucky, the english muffin underneath was completely soggy, the spinach was flavorless, the egg yolk was overdone ... you get the picture?  My husband had the much touted corned beef hash and it was so greasy that even tho we brought most of it home, we'll give it to our dog in small doses so as not to upset her digestive tract.  I've been to this restaurant before and just remembered how not-great it often is.  Too bad.
author: Theresa G.

description: I've been here about six times over the past three years.  You don't have to wait long for a table, perhaps 10-15 minutes during peak Sunday brunch.  Coffee and tea are available free of charge for those who are waiting.  Service can be inconsistent - sometimes I've had very prompt and friendly service, other times I'm flagging down the waiter.  It's not too loud nor too quiet and is particularly good for families in the outdoor patio area.  The outside noise is perfect for letting the kids run around and is successful at reducing the crying baby noise the next table over.  Usually, the menus of brunch spots can overwhelm you with the number of options on hand - this place does a great job at having the right amount of the right type of food for everyone.  It strikes a good balance - not too California-fusion-breakfast-y nor too Denny's-greasy-ish.  My favorite items on the menu are the Provence Egg Scramble, the Bodega Bay Tuna Melt, and the generously sized mimosas.  The food is consistent, can be overwhelming (recommend sharing if possible), and worth the price.  Strengths: good breakfast food at good prices, great outdoor patio on a bright SF day.  Weaknesses:  inconsistent service, perhaps too much food.  Overall, a reliable, neighborhood brunch restaurant great for everyone.
author: C C.

description: more delicious food than you can eat for $10, and i really wanted to eat it all - the soyrizo arizona is great. They do big fat mimosas too.
author: Matchak R.

description: More like 2.5 stars.  We went for brunch and ordered a savory crepe, some eggs benedict and french toast.  The crepe was decent but the other too were so disappointing.  It's the perfect size, right off 24th, cute courtyard... so much potential but so little taste.
author: Ritika A.

description: we sat out on the patio and had New Orleans eggs benedict with breakfast potatoes. the food was amazing. I would have given it 5 stars if they'd not kicked our friend with the dog out.
author: Allison D.

description: Nothing exceptional to be found here, mostly just simple plentiful plates of food.  We go to Savor every week or two to grab some dinner.   The wines are perfectly drinkable but again nothing exceptional or different.  A mob scene on weekends with the brunch crowds.  The interior is pretty nice, and I can't recall ever having a problem with any of the staff.  Savor could use a new menu, the current one has changed very little since they opened, and that's been what... 8 to 10 years or so.
author: Jan B.

description: Wonderful food!   We go here every weekend if we can.  Omelettes are awesome, crepes too.  Oh, and leave room for the potatoes.
author: Natalie A.

description: Really good for breakfast with friends. I go here for weekday breakfasts when friends are in town and it is just the best place. Excellent service. Tasty food. Lots and lots of coffee. Very mellow. Yumm.
author: Andy F.

description: Love this place for lunch- delightful staff, food is great - try the ahi salad or the Bangkock chicken salad. The outside garden is great. The place is really kid friendly.
author: Tracey M.

description:
This has always been one of our go to places when going into to the city and not wanting to spend a lot on a decent meal.  We have not been in for several months, but we both know what we like so we barely looked at the menu.  My husband didn't even open his at all.  

So our food came, it was nice, nothing spectacular, the home fries a little dry and tasted like they gave me the scrapings at the bottom of the pan. The crepes were good as usual. 

And then the bill came.  And then we noticed the $1 SF Health Fee for each of us.  Having moved away from San Francisco last year we were unaware of this new issue going on in the city recently.  When we asked our waitress she "educated" us by implying the law that was passed was for this charge on our bill.  I had to keep probing her to finally determine that the law has nothing to do with the $1 charge on our bill.  The law is about the employer's responsibility to pay health care for their employees depending on the amount of people they employ.  She kept implying though that this charge WAS the law.  I asked her if we could dispute it and she said no we could not because it is on the menu.  I could have pointed out that as regular (and used to be loyal...sorry savor you lost us...) we don't really scrutinize the menu at all and never saw it and therefore should not have to pay it, but I didn't.  

Instead we deducted the amount from our server's tip. I know you are all going to tell me how unfair this is and that she shouldn't be penalized for this, but I don't feel the customers should be penalized for a health fee that the employer is obligated to pay for.   It especially irked me because just that day I had mailed off my own health insurance payment for several hundred dollars that I pay for entirely myself without any employer contribution at all. So not only did I have to pay for my health insurance, I had to contribute to my server's insurance.  

I am all for giving people access to health insurance at reasonable fees, but this is just not the way to go about it.  Especially because it is such an unfair fee.  If the city wants to roll it into a local income tax apportioned according to income, that is fair, but to charge me a $1 when a $1 means a whole lot these days and also charge the millionaire sitting next to me the same $1 which probably doesn't hurt his pocketbook as much does not make sense.  I am especially upset that we are not even residents of San Francisco anymore and we made the very long and with gas prices these days, expensive, drive into the city just to patronize this restaurant.

My hope is that the servers will push back at their employers because they are getting short changed in their tips and the employers will reconsider this ridiculous surcharge.  

At any rate,  we will definitely think very hard next time about coming into the city to eat at any of the restaurants that charge this fee in any form.
author: mariana c.

description: Always crowded but worth the wait.  One of my favorite brunch places but I wouldn't recommend the crab cakes eggs benedict, kinda weirdly tangy.
author: Heidy M.

description: it kind of pains me to write this unfavorable review. i've been coming here for 8 years, since i moved to SF. man was savor yummy back in the day. they have a great menu with brunch items (crepes, both savory and sweet, and scrambles) and lunch specials like fish tacos (never been for dinner). we'd go all hungover and house up those yummy crepes and scrambles and potatoes and for a moment, all was right with the world. then suddenly over the years, as the place got more and more clogged with strollers and yuppie couples, the food went downhill. way downhill. i stopped going about 2 years ago (2223 brunch, i heart you) but went on a whim today to check it out. it was way worse than i remembered, even when i thought it was bad. i had an eggplant crepe, which was draped in some red NASTY sauce. i asked for no potatoes, all salad please, and my dish came out with potatoes. i didn't say anything though. the crepe was totally below average. the salad that came with the meal wasn't dressed at all. just lettuce and shredded carrots. i had a bite of bf's crab cake, which was inedible. it tasted like the bottom of the ocean. like gross, fishy. ug. anyhow, the manager guy who runs the place is such a sweetheart and even after being gone for so long, he recognized and chatted with us, asking where we'd been. i also recognized a lot of the staff who have obviously been there for years, so they clearly have a good thing going there. too bad the food sucks now. :(
author: Mary V.

description: Yesterday my friends and I set out on an adventure to Savor for a late breakfast.  Obviously on New Years Day, we weren't the only ones with this idea and had to wait for a half hour to be seated.  After being seated we ordered drinks and then sat there for another fifteen minute before our waitress came back with them.  So long, in fact, that another waitress asked if we had been helped yet.  We ordered and asked if we could get cheese on half of the potatoes.  Her response was she could bring some cheese and we could put it on half.  When our order came, she brought a pile of dry cheddar of pre-shredded cheese from a bag on  a side plate.  It was the most unappetizing, most ridiculous situation.  Plus our food tasted like it had sat awhile and our potatoes weren't hot.  After we were finished we sat there for twenty minutes with dirty dishes in front of us waiting for our check.  One of us finally had to ask for it and when it came it had $1.50 charge for the cheese we couldn't eat.  The service seemed almost non-existent, despite lots of employees running around.  When we left, folks were still waiting to be seated and we could only think of the last twenty minutes we waited to check out.  Not a recommendation for future outings.
author: Monica S.

description: sometimes, spicy breakfast food is exactly what you need (and if you don't feel like crossing the bridge to go to Vik's) Savor, and the cute little outside patio are a nice morning treat... but get ready to wait.
author: Anjali K.
